Ranked No. 2 in Tuesday's IBD, the homebuilding industry group has a number of positive factors going for it. First, the benchmark 30-year mortgage rate is still near the record low levels hit in 2012. Even as prices have moved higher, demand remains strong. In August, new-home sales rose by the fastest pace in more than seven years.While the rebound in the housing market has been in effect for several years, it still has further to go, according to Toll Bros. (TOL) CEO Doug Yearley.Last week, Yearley told CNBC that the housing recovery is just in its "fourth or fifth inning."With a new market uptrend in place, a number of leading stocks in the homebuilder group are forming bases and deserve attention.M/I Homes (MHO) is forming a consolidation with a 27.10 buy point, although an alternate entry is shaping up at 26.46.Its Accumulation/Distribution has improved sharply after falling to a D- a couple of months ago. The volatile session on Aug. 24 is a black eye in the pattern. Price action otherwise appears normal.In July, the Columbus, Ohio-based homebuilder reported a 39% gain in Q2 earnings and a 15% rise in sales. Top-line growth now has accelerated for two quarters.Taylor Morrison Home (TMHC) failed to rise from two patterns earlier this year and is trying a third time. It's forming a consolidation with a 21.65 buy point.Since March, the stock has met resistance near the 21.40 level.Lennar (LEN) is forming a double-bottom base with a 54.33 buy point. But it has more work to do.The stock is below its 10-week line and near its 40-week moving average. Its Accumulation/Distribution Rating is weak.
S&P 500 companies are on track for their first year-over-year earnings decline since 2009, led by energy woes and a sluggish global economy, with weak revenue a continued concern.

With 341 companies already reporting, the large-cap S&P 500's earnings are seen falling 1% as revenue declines 3.6%. Earnings haven't dropped since Q3 2009, but it would be the third straight decline for sales.

Energy is a huge drag. Hurt by plunging oil prices and slowing demand in China, Brazil, Russia and other nations, the energy sector is expected to notch a 59.4% earnings dive, with revenue off by 35.7%. Chevron (CVX) on Friday posted an 88% drop in earnings per share. Exxon Mobil (XOM) saw a 47% fall.

But it's not just energy. Stripping out that sector, S&P 500 earnings should grow 6.3%, the fourth straight quarter of slowing — and the smallest gain since Q1 2013. Revenue should rise 1.7% after Q2's multiyear low of 1.5%.
"The main theme still is 'energy is still pulling everything down,' making everything look worse than it really is," said Gregory Harrison, a senior research analyst at Thomson Reuters.
But the weak revenue growth remains worrisome.
"There's a concern that some of the growth in earnings is coming from cost cutting and share buybacks," Harrison said.
Consumers Drive Auto Gains

The consumer discretionary sector is a bright spot, expected to deliver 13.5% earnings growth. Auto-related companies were strong. General Motors (GM) and Ford (F) reported double-digit gains in earnings per share. Parts retailers O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY) and AutoZone (AZO) continued their tear, notching solid growth as well. A rebounding housing market powered Lennar (LEN) to a double-digit profit advance.
Amazon (AMZN) reported a surprise Q3 profit, while sales growth accelerated for a second quarter. The e-commerce giant credited the result to growth in its Amazon Prime services.
Financial earnings should show a 10.1% gain, helped by easy year-over-year comparisons for Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C), which incurred hefty litigation costs in Q3 2014.
Health care is on pace for a 10.2% profit gain, driven again by biotechs such as Gilead Sciences (GILD), where EPS grew 70%.
Apple Is Tech Earnings
Technology earnings should rise 6.5%, but much of that was driven by Apple (AAPL), which had strong iPhone sales in China. Excluding Apple, tech profits are likely to rise a meager 0.3%.
"The consumer-oriented U.S.-based multinationals, particularly those with strong brands, are doing fine in China," said Sheraz Mian, director of research at Zacks Investment Research.
Industrial firms have been hit by energy, a strong dollar and weak overseas demand. General Electric (GE) reported flat profit and a dip in sales.

On the upside, about 80% of energy companies, including Exxon and Chevron, have beaten lowball earnings estimates. The health care, tech and materials sectors all have had 80% of their companies top views.
Energy companies' earnings comparisons also should get much easier by Q2 2016.

Though it's still early, the overall ratio of Q4 negative preannouncements to positive ones is 2.4. If that holds up, it will be the first quarter to be more upbeat than the historical trend since early 2012.

New homes are being built and kitchens are getting remodeled. From a 2009 low, housing starts have been recovering, peaking in July at an annualized 1.161 million units. It's not exactly the boom year of 2005, when housing starts topped 2 million units. Also, building slowed some in August, the most recently reported month. But the recovery has been a…

In a good sign for first-time buyers, purchasing a home was at the most affordable level in two years in the first quarter, despite average home prices increasing faster than average weekly wages did over the past year, according to a RealtyTrac-Clear Capital report Thursday. The counties that were the most affordable — based on the percentage of the average…
Home Depot raised its fiscal 2015 forecasts Tuesday for the second time this year to largely reflect an improving housing market. The company also beat second-quarter sales views.

The No. 1 home-improvement chain now expects full-year earnings per share of $5.31-$5.36, up from an earlier outlook of $5.24-$5.27 and above the $5.27 that analysts had expected before the Q2 report.Home Depot (HD) also sees sales growing 5.2%-6%, up from a prior view of 4.2%-4.8% growth, while analysts see a 5.8% gain. Comparable-store sales are now seen up 4.1%-4.9% vs. previous guidance for 4%-4.6% growth.Shares climbed 2.6% to 122.80, hitting a new high, helped by a buyback authorization for an additional $3.9 billion in shares over the rest of the year, for a total of $7 billion for 2015. Rival Lowe's (LOW), which will report Q2 earnings early Wednesday, gained 0.7% Tuesday.Shares of homebuilders Lennar (LEN), D.R. Horton (DHI) and Toll Bros. (TOL) also rallied to multiyear highs.Prices, Households ReboundHome Depot's more upbeat guidance comes as a fresh batch of housing data point to an increasingly healthier market. Housing starts rose 10.1% vs. a year earlier to an annual rate of 1.21 million units, the Commerce Department said Tuesday, hitting the highest level since October 2007.Last month, the National Association of Realtors said that sales of existing homes in June reached the fastest pace in eight years, with the median price climbing 6.5% year over year to a record high of $236,400, above the prior peak set in July 2006."Home prices continue to appreciate and household formation is slightly ahead of our prior plans," Home Depot CFO Carol Tome said in a conference call.After adjusting for data-breach expenses and the sale of its HD Supply (HDS) stake, Home Depot's Q2 earnings rose 12.5% to $1.71 per share, in line with consensus. Sales for the quarter ended Aug. 2 rose 4.3% to $24.8 billion, above views for $24.7 billion.Same-store sales increased 4.2% systemwide and 5.7% at U.S. stores."We had a record number of transactions and the highest quarterly ticket going back to 2006," said CEO Craig Menear in the conference call.Interline Seen Adding BoostThough outdoor categories were pressured by weather issues in some parts of the U.S., Home Depot saw strength in maintenance and repair items, decorative lines, and professional products such as power tools and siding, among others.Meanwhile, Home Depot's pending acquisition of Interline Brands for $1.6 billion is expected to close in the third quarter. The deal will expand Home Depot's reach to professionals who repair and maintain multifamily, institutional and hospitality buildings, a change from the company's focus on products for the home."Interline Brands can tap into an incremental consumer base that the company hadn't penetrated heavily in the past," said Morningstar analyst Jaime Katz. "It's much more of a commercial business."

In times of global uncertainty, defensive stocks in industries such as utilities and supermarkets are typically considered safer bets. But a few of IBD's top 25 industry groups over the past 8 weeks may be surprising, with some relatively insulated from the negative effects of the global markets, and others even benefiting from the turmoil. Stocks were trading moderately lower and near the lows of the day heading into the noon hour Monday. The Nasdaq dropped 0.3% while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2% in the stock market today.
Volume will finish well above the level of Friday's abbreviated post-Thanksgiving level, but was tracking below average on the NYSE and Nasdaq exchange.

Among IBD 50 stocks, 16 were higher and 34 were lower. Among the top performers was Cambrex (CBM), up 2% in volume well above average. Last week the developer of active pharmaceutical ingredients broke out of a cup-with-handle base with a 52.68 buy point. The stock is trading at an all-time high.

Integrated Device Technology (IDTI), another IBD 50 stock, was up nearly 2%, also trading at an all-time high. Company management will present at the Credit Suisse Global Technology Conference Tuesday.
The worst performer on the IBD 50 was Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN), down more than 2%.
Energy names were among the day's best performing industry groups, pushed by oil prices, which were about 2% higher.
Chinese social media platform Weibo (WB) rose nearly 5% in volume running nearly triple its usual pace. It's attempting to build the right side of a deep base.

But Sohu.com (SOHU), another Chinese Internet stock, gapped down and was trading 6% lower. It was among several Chinese names downgraded by Goldman Sachs.Stocks were trading moderately lower and near the lows of the day heading into the noon hour Monday. Stocks remained lower Tuesday afternoon after recovery efforts fizzled. Hurt by media and transportation stocks, the S&P 500 was off 0.7%. The Dow Jones industrial average slumped 0.9%. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq fell a milder 0.2%, thanks to strength in biotechs. The tech-heavy index briefly reached positive territory earlier. Volume was running mixed. NYSE trade was tracking 8% higher compared with the same time Monday. Nasdaq volume was running 3% lower.In leading stocks, Southwest Airlines (LUV) gapped down and slumped 8% after lowering a key metric. Before the open, the discount carrier said operating revenue per available seat mile (RASM) will be flat to 1% lower in the fourth quarter vs. a year ago. Intraday, the stock fell 4% below a 47.27 buy point from a cup base cleared in early November.Other airlines also came under pressure after performing well Monday. Virgin America (VA) and Spirit Airlines (SAVE) dropped 4% each. United Continental (UAL), American Airlines (AAL) and Delta Air Lines (DAL) fell 3% each.Elsewhere, Outerwall (OUTR) was off its session low, but still off a whopping 24% after announcing a trio of bad news late Monday. The operator of Redbox movie-dispensing kiosks lowered its full-year guidance for earnings and sales and said it will shutter its Sampleit kiosks, where consumers can get sample products and coupons for $1. It also announced the resignation of Redbox President Mark Horak. Shares fell to a three-year low earlier in the stock market today.Leaders up in volume were few, but Adobe Systems (ADBE) rose 2% after reversing. It's now 6% past an 86.09 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. The software giant will report fiscal Q4 earnings after Thursday's close. The software giant is expected to post 60 cents a share, up 67% from a year ago.Follow Vincent Mao on Twitter @IBD_VMao.

Stocks weakened in late trade Tuesday after briefly poking into mixed territory. Worries over Greece and China have pressured equities, weighing on the stock market today.The Nasdaq fell 0.7% and the Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.3%. Meanwhile, the S&P 500 was off 0.2% after a push into positive territory was short-lived.A number of Chinese stocks have made sharp recoveries.NetEase (NTES) cut a 13% loss to 3% and 58.com (WUBA) trimmed a near-18% deficit to 6%. The latter found support near its 200-day moving average.Sohu.com (SOHU) pared a near-13% loss to 8%.On the upside, Lennar (LEN) rallied 6% and came within pennies of a 52.60 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. The stock had been up in four of the past five weeks. Its Accumulation/Distribution Rating has improved from a D- around June 17 to a B. Last month, the homebuilder delivered solid fiscal Q2 results.Cracker Barrel Old Country Store (CBRL) rose nearly 2% to its best levels in more than three months. The stock is in a cup base with a 160.04 buy point. Cracker Barrel was recently added to the midcap S&P 400.

A greater share of U.S. millennials say that they're likely to buy a home this year, adding to evidence that first-time buyers are finally entering the real estate market and fueling a jump in sales. A Realtor.com survey of site visitors taken in mid-June showed that about 65% of respondents between ages 25 and 34 said they intend to buy…

Just six companies are keeping second-quarter earnings growth in positive territory for S&P 500 businesses, which may suggest more softness to come. With 72% of S&P 500 companies having reported their performance in the last calendar quarter, earnings have grown a mere 0.9%. Revenue so far has declined 3.3% from a year ago. Excluding Apple (AAPL), Bank of America (BAC),…

Top-rated homebuilder Lennar (LEN) is trying to break out as the housing market shows continued signs of recovery.That's welcome news after the lackluster, choppy performance in recent years of most homebuilder stocks, including D.R. Horton (DHI), Ryland Group (RYL), NVR (NVR) and newer IPOs LGI Homes (LGIH) and New Home Company (NWHM). Miami-based Lennar hopes to get an additional boost…

Shares of Lennar (LEN) rose Tuesday after the nation's No. 2 homebuilder continued a string of quarters in which profit growth topped Wall Street expectations that now stands at nine.Lennar said first-quarter net earnings were $144.1 million, or an adjusted 63 cents per share, beating estimates by 11 cents a share on a 21.3% hike in revenue to $1.99 billion. Wall Street expected revenue of $1.86 billion.The results come a week after rival KB Home (KBH) reported fiscal first-quarter earnings shot up 75% to 14 cents a share, beating forecasts by 3 cents a share on a 23% rise in revenue to $678.4 million.Lennar delivered 4,832 new homes last quarter, up 12% vs. a year earlier, and its backlog rose 13% t0 7,670 homes. Chief Executive Stuart Miller said in a written statement the strength resulted from a variety of factors and came despite weak macroeconomic conditions."We continue to believe that the housing market is continuing its slow and steady recovery driven by years of under production, tight inventory levels, attractive interest rates and the lowest unemployment levels since 2008," Miller said.Lennar shares closed up 3.2% in the stock market today, touching its 200-day line, where it found resistance. It's been above its 10-week line since the beginning of March as it continues a more than five-month consolidation period with a 56.14 buy point.KB Home edged up 0.1%. Among other large homebuilders, NVR (NVR) rose 3.1%, Pulte Group (PHM) added 2.15% and Toll Bros. (TOL) advanced 3.2%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

The major indexes shifted back into positive gear in early-afternoon trade Tuesday on the back of ongoing concern about uneven economic activity overseas, as voiced by Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen during a speech at the Economic Club of New York. The Nasdaq pushed into its highest levels of the day.A day after the major indexes traded quietly, the tech-rich Nasdaq composite jumped more than 1% higher, on track for its biggest single-session gain since a nearly 0.8% lift March 16. The stock market has surprised the bears with a fairly sturdy uptrend that was confirmed by a Day 4 follow-through on Feb. 17. Yet it's been mostly piecemeal gains by high-growth stocks and slow-yet-steady moves up by defensive names.The S&P 500 gained nearly 0.7%, a pleasant reversal given that the large-cap benchmark was down nearly 0.5% in the early going. Small caps are outrunning the field, with the S&P 600 up 1.8% and the Russell 2000 up 1.5%. Volume tracked sharply higher on both exchanges.Homebuilders are rallying in the stock market today following a robust 5.8% gain in the Case-Shiller survey of January prices in its 20-city index.The industry group had a slippery start to the new year. Former Leaderboard member D.R. Horton (DHI) caved by 28% in the first six weeks of 2016, obliterating all its gains from a prior October breakout past a 28.80 entry. Yet since then, the top-tier homebuilder has carved out a new cup with handle that features a 30.68 buy point. On Tuesday, Horton surpassed the proper entry, but volume is running slightly below average. Horton's 50-day average volume is just under 6 million shares. The cup's handle passes the midpoint test (29.83 for the handle vs. 28.04 for the base).Virginia-based luxury homebuilder NVR Inc. (NVR) has been the group's leader. The stock, up 2% in heavy volume, is now up 7% past a 1665.10 early entry within a three-month consolidation. Horton and NVR are both rising, also because of better-than-expected fiscal Q1 results by Miami-based giant Lennar (LEN), up nearly 2% in big turnover. Lennar is trying to reclaim its 200-day moving average, an area of upside resistance. Lennar is 15% below a 56.04 52-week high, meaning that it, too, is coming within the typical range in which a high-quality growth stock can set up a successful breakout.Lennar posted a 26% rise in profit for the quarter ended in February, walloping the Street's consensus view by 21%. Revenue rose 21% to $1.99 billion, showing accelerating growth vs. the 14% gain seen in the November-ended fiscal fourth quarter. After-tax margin improved to 7.2% vs. 7.0% a year ago.IBD's Building-Residential/Commercial industry group is still not among the top 40 groups within the 197 rankings, yet has climbed to 76th vs. 118th three weeks ago. The group, made up of 26 companies, is up 5.6% year-to-date.

Stocks strengthened and were near session highs in late-afternoon trading Tuesday, helped by comments from Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen that were perceived as dovish once again by Wall Street.Chip-equipment stocks helped lift the Nasdaq to a 1.5% gain. Small caps also did well, with the Russell 2000 up 1.7%. The S&P 500 added 0.8%, and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.6%.Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking higher than Tuesday's levels. Money flowed into bonds, as the 10-year Treasury yield tumbled 7 basis points to 1.82%.In a speech to the Economic Club of New York, Fed Chair Janet Yellen said that it is appropriate for U.S. central bankers to “proceed cautiously” in raising interest rates.Big gainers in the Nasdaq 100 included chip-equipment firm Lam Research (LRCX). It surged past an 80.53 cup-with-handle buy point, rising 3% to 81.77. The stock is well within buy range.In economic news, consumer confidence came in better than expected, according to the latest data from the Conference Board. The index rose to 96.2 from a prior reading of 92.2. Economists expected a smaller increase to 94. Meanwhile, the S&P/Case-Shiller 20-City Composite Index for January showed home prices rising 5.7% from a year earlier, mostly in line with expectations.IBD's homebuilding group outperformed, rising about 2.5%. Lennar (LEN) popped 3% after reporting solid earnings before the open. D.R. Horton (DHI) and NVR (NVR) extended gains by more than 3% each after recent breakouts.In the stock market today, buyers were in Dave & Busters (PLAY) ahead of its earnings report, due after the close. Shares rose 4%. After a 32% pullback, the stock is only 7% off its 52-week high. The consensus estimate calls for profit of 43 cents a share, up 23% from a year before. Sales are seen rising 11% to $229.4 million.The IBD 50 outperformed nicely, with about 10 names up 2% or more. TAL Education (XRS), Broadsoft (BSFT), Prestige Brands (PBH) and Leaderboard name Edwards Lifesciences (EW) all showed gains of 3% or more.At the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude oil for May delivery slumped nearly 3% to $38.25 a barrel.

The stock market opened lower Tuesday as Wall Street looked toward a midsession report from Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen.The Dow Jones industrial lost 0.4% while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq gave up 0.3% each.A light economic calendar in the stock market today shows the March Consumer Confidence Index from the Conference Board out at 10 a.m. ET.The session's focal point is likely to be Yellen's speech on the economic outlook and monetary policy, to be delivered in New York near 12.30 p.m. ET.San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank President John Williams spoke in Singapore earlier this morning, pointing out encouraging signs in core inflation data as well as forecasting unemployment will continue to decline and inflation will reach the Fed's 2% target within two years.Dallas Federal Reserve Bank President Rob Kaplan is scheduled to speak in Austin, Texas, at 1 p.m. ET.WTI crude oil slipped nearly 3% to $38.29 a barrel, and gold added 0.6% to $1,229.60 an ounce.Oil and mining-related stocks were taking a pounding in premarket trade. Early leaders in the Dow included McDonald's (MCD), up 0.8%. Boeing (BA) and 3M (MMM) were early laggards.Among S&P 500 stocks, Lennar (LEN) popped 3% in the early going. The Miami-based homebuilder's fiscal first-quarter earnings and revenue easily outstripped consensus estimates. Deliveries and new orders showed strong growth, although gross margins contracted to 22.7% from 23.1% a year ago. The stock is stalled below resistance at its 40-week moving average, attempting to climb out of a seven-month consolidation.Louisiana-based utility Cleco (CNL) surged 13%. The company announced regulators had approved a deal for an investor group to take it private. The figures discussed when the deal was first made public in October 2014 were $55.37 a share (13% above Monday's closing price) for a total value of $4.7 billion. The investor group is reportedly led by Macquarie Infrastructure and Real Assets.Overseas, markets in Europe and Hong Kong reopened after their Easter breaks to narrowly mixed results. The Shanghai Composite dropped 1.3%

Investors in LGI Homes (LGIH) have a problem, but it's a good problem to have.Should they lock in a profit around 35%, which would likely be one of their best trades of the year, or should they hold on for the chance to make an even bigger profit? Buying a new-construction home is like purchasing a stock at its initial public offering. It's a bet on the future. Will the home turn out as you expected and be finished on time? Do you fully understand the contract and the "cost escalators"? If you're buying in phase one, will all the amenities actually get built and meet your expectations? Do you understand the warranty and your rights?

After the real estate bust, residential new construction is having a strong year. PNC Financial Services Group (PNC) is forecasting housing starts of 1.11 million for all of 2015 and 1.18 million next year, up from 1 million in 2014.
Housing starts "look good and they're getting better," said Gus Faucher, senior macroeconomist at Pittsburgh-based PNC.

But are we back to a full building boom? No. Faucher said that builders are "afraid of getting burned, so they're hesitant to expand." And he says that the building industry is experiencing a labor shortage.
The National Association of Realtors said in a news release earlier this month that homebuilding for all housing types "is underperforming in roughly two-thirds of measured metro areas."

Lawrence Yun, NAR chief economist, said, "Even as the labor market began to strengthen, homebuilding failed to keep up and is now contributing to the stronger price appreciation and eroding affordability currently seen throughout the U.S."

Top U.S. homebuilders include Toll Bros. (TOL), KB Home (KBH), PulteGroup (PHM) and Lennar (LEN). (None of these builders, nor half a dozen other publicly held builders, agreed to be interviewed for this story.)
Contracts, Upgrades, Schedules

Construction schedules are one piece of complicated new-home contracts. Experts advise making sure that you know the schedule and, more importantly, any delay provisions built into the contract. Then expect the unexpected.

Labor shortages may play a role, and delays are often "weather-based," said Linda Wilson, broker-owner of Wilson & Co. Sotheby's International Realty in San Luis Obispo, Calif. Wilson says that buyers of new homes should consider having an agent or lawyer help them review the contract.
"Some people are under the misconception that the builder's Realtor is working for them — and (he or she) is not," said Debbie Bennington, an agent with Dickson Realty in Reno, Nev.
"Your agent can help you understand the contract, but the builder isn't going to change it," said Wilson. Most builders have a standard contract that's not negotiable.

So buy from a reputable builder with strong financial backing, says Wilson. Also, be warned that the best prices come with the highest risk. Buying early, at phase one, will get you the best price, but you'll be living in a construction zone for a long time and likely without some promised amenities.
"Each phase, the price goes up," said Wilson. "If it's a new project, and you don't know much about it, then I'd wait for the second or third phase."

And figuring the final price of your home isn't easy either. Most builders offer a long list of upgrades — granite counters, hardwood floors, top-line appliances, etc. So make sure that your price estimate includes all the finishes that you want .

Comb the contract to understand the nitty-gritty — price, deposit, schedule for payments, time for performance and "what happens with delays and change orders," said David Jaffe, vice president, legal advocacy, with the National Association of Home Builders in Washington, D.C. And, Jaffe says, review what the contract says about disputes: How will they be handled, and is there an arbitration clause?
Warranties And Inspections

Often a contract will also include a "cost escalation" clause, said Eugene Graf, president of E.G. Construction in Bozeman, Mont. Graf says that costs for "Sheetrock, shingles and plywood" can change "rapidly," so builders want the contract to cover possible material cost increases. He also said that banks lending on a new home often "require a stated potential overage amount."

New homes usually come with a warranty, but the length can vary. Typically a builder will warrant all of his work for the first year. Beyond that, state laws set the rules for new home warranty coverage and length.

Some buyers opt out of having their new homes inspected as they would an existing home, because they believe that the local building department has fully vetted it. Agents say that opting out can be a huge mistake. "Residential building inspectors don't inspect everything. ... They don't inspect every home and every mechanical system," said Bennington.

Graf, however, says that the building inspectors in his area are very thorough. He also has "open job sites" so a buyer "can go see" his or her home during construction. He added: "It's one of our best selling features."

Jaffe says that unfortunately, some warranties are "vague," and buyers and builders may disagree about what's a defect and what's normal aging. On its website, the NAHB offers information to help buyers understand the construction process and quality standards.

Closing escrow and moving into a home with a major building flaw means that you won't have any leverage to get the builder to fix it quickly and to your satisfaction, and you'll be living through the repair.

Wilson says that she had one client who was ready to move into a new home, but a home inspector found that the driveway drainage was wrong and, during a big rain, water would run into the home's garage. The buyer wouldn't close on the house until the driveway was fixed. The builder initially refused to fix the driveway but eventually agreed to tear it out and replace it.
Amenities And HOA Rules

Do you fully understand the association rules of your new development? What are the parking, landscaping and exterior maintenance requirements for all properties? Can you remodel? If so, what's the permit process? If it's a senior community, what are the restrictions about having family visit?
"It's super exciting to buy new and early, but there are a lot of unknowns," said Bennington.
Even the types of homes that a builder is putting up can change.
During the bust, Bennington said, "There were communities where they said they were going to build a certain size of home, and then they built smaller homes."
You'll also want to ask detailed questions about any promised amenities, a fancy clubhouse or pool, and when they'll be finished.

Buyer beware. "Amenities may not show up for years," said Wilson, "and they may not show up at all."Buying a new-construction home is like purchasing a stock at its initial public offering. It's a bet on the future. Will the home turn out as you expected and be finished on time? Do you fully understand the contract and the "cost escalators"? If you're buying in phase one, will all the amenities actually get built and meet your expectations? Do you understand the warranty and your rights?After the real estate bust, residential new construction is having a strong year. PNC Financial Services Group (PNC) is forecasting housing starts of 1.11 million for all of 2015 and 1.18 million next year, up from 1 million in 2014.Housing starts "look good and they're getting better," said Gus Faucher, senior macroeconomist at Pittsburgh-based PNC.But are we back to a full building boom? No. Faucher said that builders are "afraid of getting burned, so they're hesitant to expand." And he says that the building industry is experiencing a labor shortage.The National Association of Realtors said in a news release earlier this month that homebuilding for all housing types "is underperforming in roughly two-thirds of measured metro areas."Lawrence Yun, NAR chief economist, said, "Even as the labor market began to strengthen, homebuilding failed to keep up and is now contributing to the stronger price appreciation and eroding affordability currently seen throughout the U.S."Top U.S. homebuilders include Toll Bros. Homebuilders, building-related stocks and retailers scored new highs Tuesday despite a broad market decline. Bolstered by a seven-year high in housing starts, soaring top-rated builders included Lennar (LEN), which gapped up 1.65, or 3%, to 55.59 in heavy trade. Shares of the Miami-based homebuilder are in buy range from a 54.06 flat-base entry and at its best levels in more…

Major averages remained under pressure in early afternoon trade as investors weighed China's sell-off and mixed U.S. housing data.The Nasdaq was down nearly 0.5%, while the S&P 500 shed 0.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average dipped 0.2%. Volume continued to run slightly higher across the board in the stock market today vs. the same time Monday.Managed care providers, discount retailers and building-related stocks were among the biggest gainers. Metal-ores miners, chipmakers and energy stocks led the downside.Housing stocks held their gains. Among the top names by Composite Rating, Lennar (LEN), Meritage Homes (MTH) and Toll Bros. (TOL) were each up more than 2%.Masco (MAS), a maker of cabinets, plumbing and other products, surged 3% to a new high in twice the average trade. The stock is 14% extended past a 25.04 flat-base entry cleared in late July.Shake Shack (SHAK) rose 4% in heavy volume. The stock edged higher the prior two sessions, but closed near its intraday low after reversing lower. The Jan. 30 IPO is trying to recover from last week's 23% drop despite reporting Q2 results that smashed views and raising its full-year sales guidance. A secondary offering last week didn't help.Among IBD 50 stocks, Ulta Beauty (ULTA) climbed 2% to a new high in brisk trade. Shares are now 9% extended from a 159.95 flat-base buy point. Analysts expect the beauty store operator to show 19% Q2 profit growth on 18% higher sales when it reports Aug. 27 after the close.On the downside, Hain Celestial Group (HAIN) gapped down and fell 6% in huge volume, falling well below its 50-day moving average for the first time in over two months. The natural and organic food products maker reported fiscal Q4 earnings and revenue that respectively met and topped views.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter: @IBD_NGondo.

The housing market is back. A closely watched sentiment index from the National Association of Home Builders hit a high not seen since the heady days of the housing bubble. Homebuilders such as D.R. Horton (DHI) and LGI Homes (LGIH) hit new highs intraday, as did home improvement giant Home Depot (HD). The NAHB index rose 1 point in August…
Stocks rolled out to a soft start Tuesday, with homebuilders and retailers stepping out to early gains.
The Nasdaq dropped 0.2%. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average trimmed 0.1% apiece.
Volume was mixed, a shade lower on the Nasdaq and up 6% on the NYSE compared with the same time Monday.

The stock market today opened feeling some mild downward pressure from overseas, where China's mainland markets dropped hard on Tuesday. The market showed a more emphatic response to mixed housing data. July housing starts came in better than expected, hitting an eight-year high. But building permits tumbled 16%. Despite the mix, homebuilders Lennar (LEN), Pulte Group (PHM) and D.R. Horton (DHI) gained more than 2% apiece.

Among leaders, SS&C Technologies (SSNC) led the IBD 50 list with a 7% gain. The developer of financial service software announced it would pay $425 million to acquire Citigroup's (C) Alternative Investor Services business. The gain sent shares 15% past a 65.10 buy point.

Next in line was Ross Stores (ROST), up 3% in a morning that saw a squall of action among major retailers. Ross is a bit more than 4% past a 53.60 cup-with-handle buy point. Ross reports Q2 results on Thursday.

Ross' gain was possibly linked to discount peer TJX (TJX), which leapt 5% after reporting stronger-than-anticipated Q2 sales and earnings. Its Q3 and full-year earnings guidance was below consensus, but comparable store sales rose 6% — double management's guidance. Tuesday's gain left shares extended, almost 7% past a 71.13 buy point.
Among other top retailers reporting results, Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) jumped 3% and Home Depot (HD) climbed 3%, while Wal-Mart (WMT) took a 2% loss.

After the close, DeVry (DV) and La-Z-Boy (LZB) are expected to report quarterly results, along with a raft of China-based companies, including Sina (SINA), Tarena International (TEDU) and Weibo (WB).Stocks rolled out to a soft start Tuesday, with homebuilders and retailers stepping out to early gains.The Nasdaq dropped 0.2%. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average trimmed 0.1% apiece.Volume was mixed, a shade lower on the Nasdaq and up 6% on the NYSE compared with the same time Monday.The stock market today opened feeling some mild downward pressure from overseas, where China's mainland markets dropped hard on Tuesday. The market showed a more emphatic response to mixed housing data. July housing starts came in better than expected, hitting an eight-year high. But building permits tumbled 16%. Despite the mix, homebuilders Lennar (LEN), Pulte Group (PHM) and D.R. Horton (DHI) gained more than 2% apiece.Among leaders, SS&C Technologies (SSNC) led the IBD 50 list with a 7% gain. The developer of financial service software announced it would pay $425 million to acquire Citigroup's (C) Alternative Investor Services business. The gain sent shares 15% past a 65.10 buy point.Next in line was Ross Stores (ROST), up 3% in a morning that saw a squall of action among major retailers. Ross is a bit more than 4% past a 53.60 cup-with-handle buy point. Shares of KB Home (KBH) were rising after the homebuilder's second-quarter results topped earnings and revenue expectations. The Los Angeles-based company's earnings fell 63% to 10 cents per share, 2 cents over views. Revenue grew 10% to $623 million, above analyst views for $616.6 million. Shares sparked up 8.1% to 16.17 in the stock market today. Housing revenues rose 8%…

Despite rising home values in many cities, homes in 90% of U.S. markets are still more affordable for buyers than historic averages, according to a joint report from RealtyTrac and Down Payment Resource out Thursday morning. But a few counties lead the pack for affordability, with the percentage of median income needed to spend each month on a house payment…

Lennar's second-quarter earnings added momentum to signs that the housing recovery is on track, but management was cautious about how enthusiastically first-time buyers will return to the market. The builder of high-end single-family homes, apartments and condominiums said Q2 earnings per share jumped nearly 30% to 79 cents, 15 cents better than estimates. Revenue climbed 31% to $2.39 billion, well…
Lennar's (LEN) second-quarter results topped Wall Street expectations as the housing market continues to improve, but orders in Houston fell.

The homebuilder said Wednesday its Q2 earnings jumped 29.5% to 79 cents per share. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were only expecting 64 cents per share. Revenue climbed 31.3% to $2.39 billion, above views for $2.02 billion.
Shares jumped 4.5% to 51.20 in premarket trading in the stock market today.

Lennar's total orders were up 17.6% year-over-year, in line with Q1's gain. But orders in its Houston market fell 9.2%, worsening from a 7% drop in Q1. Houston housing has been pressured by lower oil prices in recent quarters.
At a JPMorgan conference in May, Lennar said the Houston market was "solid" for homes under $375,000, but said high-end orders have slowed.
But the overall market for new homes appears to be strengthening. On Tuesday, the Commerce Department said new home sales reached the fastest pace since February 2008.
Last week, KB Home (KBH) reported a drop in Q2 EPS that still beat estimates. Revenue climbed on higher selling prices.
Earlier this month, Standard Pacific Corp. (SPF) and Ryland Group (RYL) said they would merge in an all-stock transaction.

Stocks whittled away at thin losses Tuesday morning as the market looked toward upcoming comments from Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen.The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 dipped 0.2% apiece. The Nasdaq backed off a fraction.Volume ticked slightly higher, up 17% on the NYSE and up a fraction on the Nasdaq relative to trade at the same time Monday.A speech scheduled just after midday in New York from Yellen, followed by a question and answer period, provides the centerpiece of the stock market today.In early economic news, home prices popped 5.8% year-over-year in January according to the S&P/Case-Shiller 20-City Composite Home Price Index. Portland, Ore., Seattle and San Francisco logged the biggest increases.  The gain was in line with economists consensus projections.Consumer outlooks improved in March, lifting the Conference Board's Consumer Sentiment Index to 96.2, a big jump above February's 92.2 reading and easily clearing consensus views for 94.Oil prices continued lower, dropping 3% and putting West Texas Intermediate just above $38 a barrel.  Oil and energy related stocks packed into the low end of the S&P 500.Boeing (BA) dropped nearly 2%, the worst slip among Dow stocks. Chevron (CVX) and 3M (MMM) were also down more than 1%. At the top of the index, McDonald's (MCD) climbed almost 1%.Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) dropped 3% to the bottom of the Nasdaq 100. Citi downgraded the stock to neutral, from buy. The note cited reduced opportunity in carrier aggregation, and said a 20% recovery in smartphone demand expected in the second half of the year was already priced into the stock. Shares are up 36% from a February low.Homebuilder Lennar (LEN) ran up 3% after a solid fiscal Q1 report. The gain lifted shares to a test of resistance at the stock's 200-day moving average.Universal Health Services (UHS) also popped 3% in heavy trade. It is up 22% from a February low and still below its 200-day line.At the extremes on the IBD 50 list, Francesca's Holdings (FRAN) climbed 3% in early action. The stock has been trading wide and loose, but holding support at the 50-day moving average. It is extended above a 15.60 buy point from a cup-with-handle base.LendingTree (TREE) slipped almost 4%. That put the stock below its 200-day moving average, and more than 7% below a 97.85 buy point in a first stage cup-with-handle base.

Pending home sales unexpectedly tumbled 2.5% in January, the National Association of Realtors said, bringing the pending home sales index down to a 106 reading.Economists had expected a 0.5% gain last month, with the consensus low end calling for a 0.4% increase, NAR said. December's numbers were revised upward to a 0.9% gain in sales.January's blizzards apparently impacted Northeast sales, but the acceleration in home prices plus minimal inventory appeared to be the main impediments to would-be buyers, Lawrence Yun, NAR chief economist, said in a statement.Compared with January 2015, pending sales inched upward by 1.4%. The South was the only region to post an increase in monthly sales, sporting a 0.3% gain. The Northeast declined 3.2%, the West fell 4.5%, and the Midwest dropped 4.9%.The index monitors transactions where sales contracts have been signed, but deals haven't yet closed. It has posted year-over-year gains for 17 consecutive months, but January's gain was the second-smallest during that time frame.Homebuilder KB Home (KBH) closed up 1.2% on the stock market today. Lennar (LEN) lost 0.76%, and PulteGroup (PHM) slipped 1.15%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

New-home sales fell in January to a seasonally adjusted rate of 494,000 units, the Commerce Department said, a sharper decline than economists forecast.January's number also came in below the low end of economists' estimates. New-home sales fell 5.2% compared with a year earlier and declined 9.2% from December's rate of 544,000 units.The median sales price for new homes was $278,800, while the average sales price was $365,700. The median price fell 4.5% vs. a year earlier, the biggest drop since January 2012.The seasonally adjusted rate of new homes for sale by the end of January was 238,000, representing a supply of 5.8 months at the current rate of sales.Shares of homebuilders fell Wednesday morning, but pared losses or turned higher in the afternoon as the overall market reversed higher. KBHome (KBH) rose 3.4% in the stock market today. Lennar (LEN) rose 0.1% and Pulte (PHM) edged down 0.1%.

Home-builder sentiment slipped slightly, with optimism still strong though down a smidgen from December. The National Association of Home Builders' Housing Market Index notched a reading of 60 in January, down one point from the previous month but well above the 50 mark that divides contraction from expansion. Economists had forecast a 62 reading.

The gauge of prospective first-time buyers fell to 44 from December's 46. The six-month outlook for future sales slipped to 63 from December's 66 reading, marking the lowest reading since May of last year.The West still leads in terms of home-builder confidence, with a stellar 73 reading. The South reported a reading of 60, and the Midwest was at 58. The Northeast, the smallest region for new homes, was 47.Stocks of home builders were mixed on the stock market today. KB Home (KBH) shares fell 1.3% to 10.22. D.R. Horton (DHI) rose 1.8% to 27.12. Toll Brothers (TOL) fell 0.6% to 28.91, and Lennar (LEN) rose 1.1% to 41.36.Follow Ciaran McEvoy on Twitter @IBD_CMcEvoy and on Facebook.
Housing delivered stronger-than-expected data again Thursday, confirming that its rebound is for real and may even be enough to power the economy as the factory sector flags.

Sales of new single-family homes ran at an annual pace of 552,000 in August, the strongest in 7-1/2 years, the Commerce Department said. August's rate was 22% higher than a year earlier, making it the 9th straight month of double-digit yearly gains.

The current sales pace would take 4.7 months to clear all inventory, well below the long-run average of 6 months. Even so, prices ticked up only 0.5% in August. The average yearly price gain for new homes in 2015 is 3.6%, down from an average 7.1% in 2014. That slower pace of price growth helped draw more first-time buyers to existing home sales in August.
Lean supply, along with improving fundamentals like a jobless rate at a 7-year low and subdued consumer inflation, is helping bolster demand for housing.
Builders Are Benefiting

It's also helping homebuilders. KB Home (KBH) on Thursday reported double-digit gains in orders and deliveries, and said that its average sales price rose 9%. Lennar (LEN) on Monday noted "significant pent-up demand" as it beat earnings estimates.

"Sales of new homes on which construction has not yet started have accounted for over one-third of all new home sales over the past seven months," wrote Regions Bank chief economist Richard Moody Thursday.
Housing's long-awaited resurgence is good news at a time when another economic engine, manufacturing, has lost steam.
The price of oil is down more than 50% since mid-2014, wreaking havoc with many firms' capital budgets. The dollar's jump to the highest in a decade also has sunk demand for U.S. exports.

In a separate report Thursday, the Commerce Department said that orders for durable goods fell 2% in August; orders excluding the volatile transportation sector were flat, below estimates for an 0.3% gain. Both measures have been below year-ago levels in every month since February.
On Thursday, construction and mining equipment maker Caterpillar (CAT) said that it will slash thousands of jobs as it aims to cut costs by about $1.5 billion.

"Absolutely, manufacturing is the weak part of the economy," said Jim O'Sullivan, chief U.S. economist for analyst High Frequency Economics. He believes that the sector may weaken even further in September or October. But for home sales, "it's pretty clear the trend has been up."
Housing will start to contribute more to the economy as the mix of new homes shifts from multifamily homes to single-family, O'Sullivan said.

Builders broke ground on more homes in July than in the past 8 years, and single-family starts rose to a 7-year high in August, though they still make up a smaller portion of all starts than before the downturn.

While manufacturing makes up 12% of the economy, "the other 88% is chugging along," O'Sullivan noted. Jobless claims are at levels once associated with full employment, a boon for the housing market in the future.Housing delivered stronger-than-expected data again Thursday, confirming that its rebound is for real and may even be enough to power the economy as the factory sector flags.Sales of new single-family homes ran at an annual pace of 552,000 in August, the strongest in 7-1/2 years, the Commerce Department said. Home loan applications surged in the most recent week, the Mortgage Bankers Assn. said. Its composite index jumped 13.9%, the biggest weekly move since January.

Applications to refinance were up 18% during a week characterized by volatile shifts in rates, thanks to the Federal Reserve meeting. The average 30-year fixed rate was little changed by week's end, but other products, like 15-year fixed and adjustable rate mortgages, saw declines. Refinancing activity has stayed stronger than expected as rates remain low, a boon to consumer discretionary spending.

Purchases leapt 9% during the week, MBA said. Precise year-on-year calculations are difficult because of shifts in the Labor Day holiday timing, but the average index level in September is 23% higher than the same period last year. That tracks with most other data, like sales figures, that show a healing housing market.

Among homebuilder stocks, Lennar (LEN), D.R. Horton (DHI), Pulte (PHM) and KB Home (KBH) all rose modestly in morning trade in the stock market today. Lennar topped earnings forecasts on Monday. KB Home reports results Thursday.

Meanwhile, Wells Fargo (WFC), the No. 1 mortgage lender in the U.S., was little changed Wednesday morning. Wells Fargo stock has been slumping, partly on the overall market and partly due to the Fed's decision not to raise rates, which likely would have meant wider loan spreads for banks.Home loan applications surged in the most recent week, the Mortgage Bankers Assn. said. Homebuilder stocks jumped Thursday, and D.R. Horton (DHI) nailed down some of the biggest gains. Despite a slowdown in mortgage applications for new-home purchases in July, D.R. Horton and other builders have been boosted by a downtrend this summer in the 10-year Treasury yield, which helps keep a lid on mortgage rates. China's devaluation of the yuan has helped push…

The housing market is back. A closely watched sentiment index from the National Association of Home Builders (NAHB) hit a high not seen since the heady days of the housing bubble.Homebuilders D.R. Horton (DHI) and LGI Homes (LGIH) hit new highs, as did home improvement giant Home Depot (HD).The NAHB index rose 1 point in August to 61. Two subindexes, measuring current sales conditions and the next 6 months, were relatively unchanged at high levels: 66 and 70, respectively.The traffic index rose by 2 points. At 45, it's still below the neutral 50 mark — but traffic has been above that mark only briefly, and that was just before the bubble burst.If homebuilders are bullish, it's probably a signal that housing is in good shape. It could also be a good sign for the rest of the economy, since a humming housing market propels so much other activity, especially hiring.Horton shares rose 2% to a 9-year high Monday. LGI fell lightly after making an all-time high; Lennar (LEN) rose 3% and PulteGroup (PHM) 1%.Meanwhile, in the mobile software industry, GrubHub (GRUB) is facing pressure in online food delivery from rivals led by ride-summoning service Uber, which recently began highlighting its big push into food delivery with a new look on its app.Uber had buried the UberEats app at the bottom of its site. But starting last week, UberEats has appeared prominently next to Uber's car-summoning icon. It's the latest salvo in the app-based food delivery service wars, wrote Cowen & Co. analyst Kevin Kopelman in a research report on Monday."We view this as a subtle but significant change recognizing food delivery as Uber's second major category ahead of a broader rollout," wrote Kopelman.Uber is hiring for its UberEats on-demand meal-delivery service in at least nine U.S. cities and could operate in as many as 15 cities in coming months, Kopelman says."UberEATS remains small today in both geographic scope, food options and user adoption. However, Uber's recent moves signal some traction in markets where UberEATS has rolled out and point to aggressive expansion of food delivery as a core Uber service," Kopelman said.Uber is pioneering the "ultrafast" food category, offering a limited selection of prepared foods in thermal bags that couriers deliver within 10 minutes for a flat all-in delivery fee of $3 to $4.Competition from Uber and other companies that deliver food — which include Google (GOOGL) and Amazon.com (AMZN) — is pressuring GrubHub's order growth, which slowed to a 25% year-over-year gain in Q2 2015 from 33% in Q4 2014, wrote Kopelman. "We note that new competitors, most notably Postmates, Yelp (YELP)-owned Eat24, DoorDash, Munchery, Caviar and UberEATS, are on track to capture 50% of U.S. industry growth in fiscal 2015 vs. 25% in 2014, and (excluding Uber) have raised $500 million year to date," Kopelman wrote.

Builder stocks jumped Thursday despite a report from the Mortgage Bankers Association that showed a slowdown in mortgage applications for new-home purchases in July vs. the previous month. PulteGroup (PHM), D.R. Horton (DHI) and Toll Bros. (TOL) were trading up around 3% in the stock market today at midafternoon. Lennar (LEN) rose 2%, as did NVR (NVR), LGI Homes (LGIH)…

Stocks remained deep in the red going into the last hour of trading as rate-hike concerns and falling commodity prices continued to weigh. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 1%, the S&P 500 shed 0.8%, and the Nasdaq was down 0.6%. Volume was higher across the board in the stock market today, vs. the same time Wednesday.
St. Louis Fed President James Bullard said in a speech earlier today that the Fed should start hiking interest rates based on "prudence alone."

Auto parts retailers, nonalcoholic beverage makers and energy stocks, weighed down by falling crude oil prices, were among the biggest losers. Gainers included department stores, software and apparel stocks.

Kohl's (KSS) gapped up and rose 6% in busy trade, recovering most of its prior-session loss. The department store operator, which fell nearly 6% Wednesday, reported Q3 earnings, revenue and same-store sales above views.

Dillard's (DDS) was up 4%, while Nordstrom (JWN) and Macy's (M) climbed 2% each. On Wednesday, these stocks fell 8%, 4% and 14%, respectively, after Macy's revealed disappointing sales and lowered guidance. At least four analysts cut their Macy's price targets Thursday, but Cowen & Co. raised its price target.

Ten IBD 50 names were up, led by NetEase (NTES), which rose 3% to clear a 154.98 buy point in heavy volume after reporting better-than-expected Q3 results.. TAL Education Group (XRS) and LinkedIn (LNKD) each gained 2% in above-average trade.

Chinese online retailer JD.com (JD) surged 4% in volume after reporting a 130% increase in Singles' Day sales from last year. Singles' Day, which occurred Wednesday, is the biggest shopping day of the year in China. JD.com's chief rival Alibaba (BABA), which also scored record sales for the day, was slightly lower.

Stocks clawed their way back from a morning slump Tuesday, pushing the Nasdaq to a new all-time high. Volume was slightly above average on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq exchanges, according to preliminary data.
The three major indexes finished 0.1% higher in the stock market today.
Netflix was up after hours. It announced a 7-for-1 stock split effective July 15.

Also after hours, Boeing named Dennis Muilenburg, the chief operating officer, to succeed W. James McNerney as CEO. McNerney continues as chairman. Boeing's stock was unchanged in early after-hours trade.
Facebook (FB) rose nearly 4% in heavy trade, breaking out of a flat base.
IBD 50 stocks were about evenly split. Ambarella (AMBA), which pulled the index of leading growth stocks lower on Monday, bounced back and rose 8% on an analyst's positive comments.
But Sonic (SONC), another IBD 50 stock, tanked, destroying a base in progress, taking a 10% loss in response to lowered guidance.
Also before the open Wednesday, homebuilder Lennar (LEN) will report earnings. Analysts are expecting 64 cents a share, a 5% increase from a year earlier.
Before the open Wednesday, the Commerce Department will release final Q1 GDP, which is expected to decline 0.6%.

A baseball or basketball team will have a tough time without a good defense.Likewise, making money in stocks is challenging without a sound selling strategy.Half the battle is buying the right stock at the right time, but it's equally important to know when to sell — on the upside and the downside.Whether the stock didn't pan out the way you hoped or the market falls into a correction, you risk losing far more money if you don't have a set cut-off point at which to get out of a losing position.That's why IBD often stresses the importance of the 7%-to-8% sell rule. If a stock falls 7% or 8% below your buy point — not its peak price — exit the position without asking questions. Don't let a small loss spiral into a bigger one."The whole secret to winning big in the stock market is not to be right all the time, but to lose the least amount possible when you're wrong," founder and Chairman William O'Neil wrote in "How to Make Money in Stocks."It's also important to keep in mind that there are times when you don't have to wait for a stock to fall 7% to 8% from the entry before cutting it loose. That rule of thumb is the absolute limit. Investors are at greater risk of losses when the market uptrend is under pressure or in correction.So when the market isn't in a confirmed uptrend and a stock you own isn't behaving well, it's perfectly acceptable to get out of a position ahead of a 7% to 8% decline. In this case, cut your losses at 3% to 5% to help preserve your capital. You can then put those funds to work in better-performing stocks or raise cash for the next uptrend.Staying mostly in cash is prudent when the market is in a steep correction or a bear market. When the market is in an uptrend but trading is choppy, aim to sell positions at an even lower threshold, perhaps at 2% or 3% below the buy point.Take Lennar (LEN), for example, back in 2013. The homebuilder emerged from a V-shaped cup base on March 20 in heavy volume. The next session, it pulled back to form another similar cup base. Lennar climbed past a new buy point at 44 on May 14, but closed slightly below it.Lennar attempted to clear the entry, but reversed lower after hitting intraday highs (1). Then the stock fell further in heavier trade. It fell more than 5% intraday from the buy point, before settling for a 3.9% loss from the 44 entry by May 22.The stock staged a 3% upside reversal in fast turnover the next day, though it failed to reclaim its buy point. Lennar again fell as much as 5% during a bearish reversal two sessions later (2).That turned out to be the last-ditch chance to cut losses short. On May 29, the stock sank 4%, slicing its 50-day moving average in heavy volume to fall more than 8% below the buy point (3). From there, it fell as much as 30% from the 44.40 peak to its mid-August low.In addition to a lack of upside volume, Lennar's relative strength line lagged as it tried to break out. Distribution days had also been piling up in the market while Lennar was working on both bases. Shortly after the stock's breakdown, the market outlook changed to under pressure, and by mid-June to a correction.

After a few rocky years, housing has found its sea legs. Sales of existing homes popped 5.1% in May to an annual rate of 5.35 million, more than expected and nearly a 6-year high, the National Association of Realtors said. Sales were up 9.2% vs. a year earlier and have increased on a yearly basis for eight straight months. Inventory…

For further hints into how well the spring selling season for new homes has been faring, Lennar (LEN) on Wednesday will report results for its second quarter ended May 31, including the much watched metric for new orders. Lennar is the nation's second-largest builder by market capitalization after D.R. Horton (DHI). It's the first of the major homebuilders to report…

Stocks opened in the hole on Wednesday, as oil prices sagged ahead of weekly inventories data, and earnings reports took a toll in early trade. Volume eased on the stock market today, dipping 10% on the Nasdaq and 2% on the NYSE, relative to action at the same time Tuesday. Many institutional traders were holding fire ahead of the Federal…

D.R. Horton (DHI) reported disappointing fiscal first-quarter revenue as home sales fell across the nation except for the southeastern region, though its backlog is well supplied for the upcoming spring home-selling season.The Fort Worth, Texas-based company earned 42 cents a share during its fiscal Q1, up 7.7% from a year earlier and beating by a penny estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. It's the sixth consecutive quarter of EPS growth for D.R. Horton, though earnings growth decelerated for the second straight quarter. Revenue rose 4.5% to $2.3 billion, missing estimates of $2.4 billion. It was the 18th straight quarter of revenue growth, but the weakest of those quarters.Homes closed rose 1% to 8,061 for the three-month period ended Dec. 31, compared to 7,973 homes a year earlier. Backlog rose 15% to 10,665 homes with a total value of $3.2 billion, up 16%. The company's cancellation rate fell one percentage point to 23%.Southeast region home sales rose 13.1% to 2,691, but fell everywhere else.Horton didn't give guidance in its earnings report, but Donald R. Horton, the company's chairman, said in a conference call that the company expects full-year revenue in a range between $12 billion and $12.5 billion.Shares closed down 4.7% on the stock market today. D.R. Horton has traded below its 200-day moving average since Jan. 7. Its current IBD Composite Rating is 94 out of 99, meaning it trades better than 94% of other publicly traded businesses.Other homebuilders' shares fell as markets turned lower Monday. Lennar (LEN) fell 3.8%. KB Home (KBH) slipped 3.9%. Toll Bros. (TOL) fell 4.5% and PulteGroup (PHM) fell 4.2%.

Homebuilder stocks are raising the roof. IBD's Building-Residential/Commercial industry group ranks 29th among IBD's 197 groups, up from No. 48 one week ago and 103 going back 13 weeks. Mutual funds have played a key role, with 967 mutual funds holding D.R. Horton (DHI), the largest homebuilder, as of June 30, up from 892 as of Dec. 31. And 1,040…

Housing and discount retailers shrugged off modest to moderate declines by the major market indexes to post big gains Tuesday. The Nasdaq, weighed down by chip and computer stocks, lost 0.6%. The S&P 500 gave up 0.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.2%. Volume ended slightly higher across the board in the stock market today, according to preliminary figures.
Automakers, managed care providers and homebuilders gained more than 1% each among IBD's 197 industry groups. Metal ore miners, chipmakers and biotechs lagged.

Homebuilders and related stocks outperformed, boosted by a seven-year high in housing starts and Monday's bullish housing index data. Among top-rated builders, Lennar (LEN) rose 4% while Meritage Homes (MTH), MI Homes (MHO) and Toll Bros. (TOL) each gained nearly 3%.

Building-related stocks rallied too. Home Depot (HD) climbed 3% to a record best after reporting Q2 results above views and boosting its full-year outlook. Cabinet and plumbing products maker Masco (MAS) advanced 3% to an eight-year high. It's now extended 14% past a 25.04 flat-base buy point.

Off-price retailer TJX (TJX) gapped up and soared 7% to an all-time high, also after beating Q2 forecasts on both the top and bottom lines. Rival Ross Stores (ROST) gapped up and rose 4% on busy trade ahead of its Q2 report, which is due Thursday. It was the biggest gainer on the IBD 50.
Economic data on tap for Wednesday include the Consumer Price Index for July, weekly petroleum inventory and minutes from the Federal Open Market Committee meeting.

Flippers reaped generous returns on their investments in the second quarter, with the average gross profit on completed single-family home flips up significantly from a year earlier, according to a report by foreclosure data company RealtyTrac. But, the report cautioned, slowing home price gains and rising mortgage rates could soon take the bloom off the rose for flippers, who have…

U.S. home prices will rise moderately this year and next as demand picks up but inventory stays low, a panel of housing economists said Friday. Rents rising, perhaps faster, are expected to benefit landlords, while homebuilders undergo a continuing profit pinch.After a 6% gain the last 12 months, home prices should rise 5% both this year and next, predicts Frank Nothaft, chief economist at property analytics provider CoreLogic (CLGX)."By the end of 2017, I think we'll be back up to the peak where we were in 2006," he told the National Association of Real Estate Editors (NAREE) conference in Miami, Fla. "But those are nominal prices ... in inflation-adjusted terms, prices will still be about 20% below the 2006 peak."He sees home sales also rising 5% this year to the highest since 2009.Homebuying is happening amid stock market gains and better consumer confidence, which hit a 5-month high in a University of Michigan survey out Friday.Panelists saw a variety of reasons for a low inventory of existing homes for sale. They ranged from owners hesitating to sell because they don't find a suitable replacement home to reluctance to move after refinancing a mortgage at a very low rate.Also, large investors who have bought homes are not putting them back on the market, said National Association of Realtors chief economist Lawrence Yun.Whatever the reasons, the low-inventory phenomenon has an impact on builders, said David Crowe, senior economist at the National Association of Home Builders."New-home sales come primarily from existing-home sellers," he said. "If we're not getting existing sellers to sell their house, we can't find someone to buy their new house."So "builders aren't going to build what they think they can't sell."That's despite a 30-year mortgage rate that Yun expects to end the year at an average of just 4.3%.Crowe sees single-family housing construction starts rising from 647,000 in 2014 to 726,000 this year and 935,000 in 2016.He notes that after the housing downturn and recession, when builders braked with the marketplace, their supply chains — from labor to lending — were interrupted .Now, Crowe says, "builders are seeing a profit squeeze — they're having to pay higher prices for their land, and they're having to pay more for labor ... and they're suffering either from no credit or very expensive credit."A lack of credit availability through small community banks particularly affects regional and local builders, the NAREE panelists said.One thing affecting the housing supply is that many existing homes have become rentals, as owners and small investors seek income streams and as the institutional single-family-home buyers that Yun referenced act as landlords."We've had a big increase in the one-family-home component of the rental stock," Nothaft said."We've seen rents rise on single-family homes about 4% this year. ... In some markets, double-digit increases in rent and in other markets growth (are) a lot weaker," he added, citing April data.Zillow (Z) chief economist, Stan Humphries, sees rents up more than home prices."Rents are rising 4.3% year over year while home prices are up 3.3% year over year (in May)," he said. "We're very tight in terms of rental vacancies. It's no surprise why rents are on a tear in this country."Humphries says that he continues to be very bullish on rental demand, noting that while some renters will move into homes, millennials and restrained wage growth support the rental market."The kid in your basement is not going to go buy a house," Humphries said. "He's going to move into rental stock."The builder stocks in IBD's Building-Commercial/Residential industry group are up a collective 10% this year. Three of the five largest by market cap are highly rated by IBD, with a Composite Rating of 89 or better out of a potential 99: Lennar (LEN), D.R. Horton (DHI) and NVR (NVR). Among builders with a market cap of at least $1 billion, two more have a Composite Rating that high: Ryland Group (RYL) and Tri Pointe Homes (TPH), both with a 91.Homebuilders rallied after the largest by market cap, Lennar, beat analyst estimates in its second quarter earnings report Wednesday. And Lennar stock rose 5%.The builder's gross margin on home sales of 23.8% was down from 25.5% a year earlier."Gross margin percentage on home sales decreased primarily due to an increase in land costs, partially offset by an increase in the average sales price of homes delivered," Lennar said in its report.KB Home (KBH) stock has jumped 16% since its earnings report June 19 that topped analyst estimates. That builder's gross profit margin came in at 16%, down from 18.9% a year earlier, attributed in the report to "higher land and construction costs, increased pricing pressure in certain markets, start-up field costs associated with new community openings, and an increase in the amortization of previously capitalized interest."
Stocks slumped out of the starting block Wednesday, with both blue chips and growth stocks showing little verve.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 0.4%. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 shaved off 0.1% apiece.
Volume was quiet, 6% lower on the Nasdaq and down 4% on the NYSE, compared to trade at the same time Tuesday.

The stock market today received a no-news report on Q1 GDP, as the Commerce Department made a slight upward revision to initial growth estimates for the quarter. The final tally, minus 0.2%, was better than the prior estimate of a 0.7% decline, and in line with consensus expectations.
DuPont (DD) staked out the low-end of the Dow, reaching toward a 2% decline. Staples (SPLS) was the loser among Nasdaq 100 stocks, down almost 3%.

Lennar (LEN) plowed up to a 6% gain after its fiscal second quarter sales and earnings cleared consensus expectations. The gain hoisted shares to within 5% of a 53.77 buy point in a two-month cup base. Other homebuilders also rallied, with D.R. Horton (DHI) and Pulte Group (PHM) up 2% each.

Netflix (NFLX) bumped up 2% to peg a new high. The streaming entertainment service and content developer announced Tuesday it will enact a 7-for-1 stock split, effective July 15. Shares are up 43% since clearing a 486.60 cup-base buy point in mid-April.

Chip equipment leader Applied Materials (AMAT) popped 2% at the opening bell. Goldman Sachs upgraded the stock to conviction buy, from buy, citing a pickup in chip-industry etch and deposition tool purchases. Applied Materials shares have been correcting since March.
Apple (AAPL) gained a bit more than 1%. The stock is pecking away at the underside of its 50-day moving average in the fifth week of a shallow consolidation.
Leading stocks opened in a sour mood, with more than four of every five IBD 50 issues falling in early trade. Gains were very modest, with no IBD 50 stocks reaching a 0.5% gain.

Stock futures veered unevenly lower on a heavy slate of earnings reports ahead of Wednesday's open.
Dow futures were down 30.3 points below fair market value, but had pared early losses. Nasdaq 100 futures were down 62.4 points and sliding. S&P 500 futures were also ticking lower, down 7.2 points.

This week's economic calendar finally kicks into gear at 9 a.m. ET, with the Federal Housing Finance Agency's May Housing Price Index. June existing-home sales numbers from the National Association of Realtors are due out at 10 a.m., with weekly crude oil inventories from the Energy Information Administration to follow at 10:30.

Big names were moving ahead of the open in the stock market today, with Boeing (BA) (up 1%), Microsoft (MSFT) (down 4%), Coca-Cola (KO) (up 1%) and Whirlpool (WHR) (up 2%) responding to their quarterly reports.

Apple (AAPL) grabbed the early headlines. The stock slid more than 6% in premarket trade, despite its late-Tuesday report of a better-than-forecast 44% earnings gain, a 33% surge in sales and expanded profit margins in its fiscal third quarter.

Fourth-quarter revenue guidance didn't quite measure up, however, and the company separately didn't break out sales of the new Apple Watch. Apple shares ended Tuesday just above their 50-day moving average in a shallow, two-month consolidation.
Apple suppliers were also taking an early beating, with Cirrus Logic (CRUS) and Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) down more than 5%.

Vasco Data Security (VDSI) collapsed 9% after the company admitted in a regulatory filing released Tuesday that some of its products may have been sold into Iran via its European subsidiary and a third-party distributor.

The sale potentially violated federal rules prohibiting transactions with "proliferators of weapons of mass destruction and their supporters." Vasco shares had pulled back sharply from a late June high to test support at their 40-week moving average.
Illumina (ILMN) dimmed 9%, falling hard after reporting late Tuesday its Q2 earnings topped; revenue missed analyst consensus expectations for the first time in six years.

The maker of large-scale genetic screening equipment also raised its Q3 earnings guidance in line with projections. The stock finished Tuesday just below Monday's high and 6% above a 223.18 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern.

Blackhawk Network (HAWK) climbed 4%. The distributor of prepaid gift cards reported late Tuesday its sales and earnings cleared analyst estimates. The IBD 50 and Leaderboard stock ended Tuesday at the top of its buying range, 4.8% above a 40.67 buy point in a cup base.

Overseas, Europe's markets were under pressure near midday. A vote in Greece was expected to pass further fiscal measures required by its recent bailout agreement with eurozone creditors, but could show declining support for Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras. London's FTSE 100 showed the deepest loss among benchmark indexes, down 1%.
In China, Hong Kong's Hang Seng index fell 1%, while the Shanghai Composite added 0.2%. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 in Japan fell 1.2% as the yen rose against the dollar.

Pending home sales fell for the third time in four months, the IMF's chief sees disappointing growth next year and China halted some foreign banks' foreign exchange activities as the yuan comes under increasing pressure.
Pending home sales fell again

The Pending Home Sales Index declined 0.9% in November, the third drop in four months, as higher home prices and limited supply of homes for sales continue to curb demand, according to the National Association of Realtors. The forward-looking gauge is based on existing-home contract signings that should translate into actual closed sales in a month or two. The index rose just 2.7% vs. November 2014, the smallest yearly gain since October 2014. Modest monthly gains in the Midwest and South were offset by larger declines in the Northeast and West.

The report gives homebuilders such as D.R. Horton (DHI), Lennar (LEN) and LGI Homes (LGIH) reasons to step up activity, but also to be cautious. And that's what they've been doing. D.R. Horton and Lennar shares rose fractionally in the stock market today, with D.R. Horton closing in on a recent long-time high. LGI Homes rose 2.6%.
IMF not high on 2016 growth

Global economic growth will be "disappointing" next year, IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde said in a guest article for the German newspaper Handelsblatt. Higher U.S. interest rates and a Chinese economic slowdown are contributing to problems such as a sharp slowdown in global trade and weak raw material prices' impact on commodity-producing nations, she said .
China suspends banks' FX ops

The People's Bank of China halted some foreign banks from some foreign exchange business through March, according to multiple reports. Reuters said it was at least 3 foreign banks, Bloomberg said at least 2, with both citing sources. Three months ago the PBOC ordered banks to watch closely to prevent illicit cross-border currency arbitrage. The spread between the offshore and onshore yuan values has widened since Aug.'s devaluation in anticipation of further moves. Both are at the lowest levels vs. the dollar since 2011. Many experts see China allowing more depreciation since the IMF added the yuan to its reserve currencies in Nov.
U.K. home prices strong

Dec. prices rose 0.8%, the biggest gain since April, according to a Nationwide survey. The annual home price gain was 4.5%, an 8-month high. London remained hot, with a 12.4% yearly gain in Q4. Nationwide indicated that home prices will rise an average 3%-6% in 2016.
 Italian producer prices fell 4.2% vs. a year earlier, the biggest annual drop since Oct. 2009.
COMING UP THURSDAY
 Initial jobless claims for the week ended Dec. 26, 8:30 a.m. ET (forecast: 270,000).
 Chicago factory activity index for Dec., 9:45 a.m. ET (forecast: 50).
