Nationwide indicated that home prices will rise an average 3%-6% in 2016. Italian producer prices fell 4.2% vs. a year earlier, the biggest annual drop since Oct. 2009. Initial jobless claims for the week ended Dec. 26, 8:30 a.m. ET (forecast: 270,000). Chicago factory activity index for Dec., 9:45 a.m. ET (forecast: 50). U.S. oil rig count for the week ended Dec. 31, 1 p.m.

The Pending Home Sales Index declined 0.9% in November to the lowest level since January, the National Association of Realtors said Wednesday. It was the third drop in four months, as higher home prices and a limited supply of homes for sales continue to curb demand.The index rose just 2.7% vs. November 2014, the smallest yearly gain since October 2014. Modest monthly gains in the Midwest and South were offset by larger declines in the Northeast and West.The forward-looking pending home sales gauge is based on existing-home contract signings that should translate into actual closed sales in a month or two. However, existing-home sales — based on closings — may rebound in December. Existing-home sales tumbled in November, in part due to new mortgage disclosure rules pushing some closings into December.Homebuilders such as D.R. Horton (DHI), Lennar (LEN), PulteGroup (PHM) and LGI Homes (LGIH) have been cautious about boosting construction despite tight supply and favorable fundamentals, such as steady job growth and pent-up demand from millennials. Single-family starts did hit an eight-year high in November. D.R. Horton rose 0.2% to 32.67 on the stock market today, close to its recent nine-year high of 33.10. Lennar advanced 0.9%. PulteGroup was little changed, while LGI Homes popped 2.5%.

U.S. home prices rose 5.2% in October vs. a year earlier amid tight supply, according to the latest S&P/Case-Schiller data, which should be good news for homebuilders such as D.R. Horton (DHI), Lennar (LEN) and LGI Homes (LGIH).It was the fourth straight month of acceleration and the best gain since July 2014. Homes appreciated 5.5% in 20 key cities, with 12 metro areas showing faster rises. Portland, San Francisco and Denver led with 10.9% advances.Economic conditions support housing demand, but limited inventory is what's fueling higher prices. Homebuilders have been cautious about building, with D.R. Horton among those also citing labor shortages. But single-family housing starts rose to an eight-year high in November, the Commerce Department reported this month. That should eventually bolster supply of new homes and help boost affordability for first-time buyers.D.R. Horton stock rose 1% to 32.61 on the stock market today, close to a Dec. 2 nine-year high of 32.10. Lennar climbed 0.9% while LGI Homes shot up 4.1%.

Earnings, sales, deliveries, new orders and backlog all rose at least 10% for homebuilder Lennar (LEN) in the fourth quarter, indicating solid housing demand, but land costs weighed on and deliveries in the Houston market fell.The results came after Toll Bros. (TOL) last week reported underwhelming results, topping estimates on sales but missing on profit.Lennar shares closed down 2.4% on the stock market today, hitting the lowest levels since late September. Toll Bros. fell 3%.Lennar's earnings per share rose 13% from a year ago to $1.21, topping views for $1.07. Sales rose 14% to $2.945 billion, just short of views for $2.995 billion. Deliveries and new orders rose 10%, although deliveries slowed from the previous quarter, while the company's backlog of homes increased 14%."While the Federal Reserve announced the first interest rate increase in nine years, it stated that the increase was a sign of confidence in the economy," CEO Stuart Miller said in a statement. "We believe that improving employment levels, wage growth and consumer confidence will continue to keep the housing market on its slow and steady recovery. Thus, we believe we are very well positioned to achieve another year of company-wide improvement in 2016."Miller said the company's more efficient Everything's Included homes, which come pre-packaged with a variety of features, "helped mitigate the impact of a tight labor market."Selling, general and administrative expenses as a portion of revenues from home sales came in at 9.2%, better than 9.6% a year ago.Still, gross margin on home sales slipped to 24.6% from 25.6%, largely due to rising land costs. The company said deliveries rose in all homebuilding segments except for southeast Florida and Houston.The effects of low oil prices have hurt oil companies, many based in Texas, and the pain felt by those companies has rippled into the real estate market.Follow Bill Peters on Twitter @IBD_BPeters.

The housing recovery momentum slowed a bit in May as the number of homes with foreclosure filings hit the highest level in more than a year, according to a report released Thursday by housing data and analytics provider RealtyTrac. Foreclosure filings — default notices, scheduled auctions and bank repossessions — were reported on 126,868 U.S. properties in May, up 16%…
Stocks flew into Friday's session in tightly mixed formation, with earnings news squarely at the center of early action.
The Nasdaq climbed 0.5%, passing its June 24 peak to notch a new high. The S&P 500 dipped 0.2%, the Dow Jones industrial average backed off 0.5%.

Volume was higher, up 6% on the Nasdaq while surging 51% on the NYSE. The Nasdaq ran hot, with Google (GOOGL), Facebook (FB), Priceline.com (PCLN) and Tesla Motors (TSLA) powering to the front of the Nasdaq 100. Dow stocks were cooler, with only a handful of issues gaining ground, and none of those as much as a half-percent.

Positive economic news appeared to have little to no impact on the stock market today. Consumer price data showed inflation action in check, increasing in line with expectations during June. Big homebuilders Toll Bros. (TOL), Pulte (PHM), Lennar (LEN) and D.R. Horton (DHI) slipped, despite a surge in July housing starts and building permits.

Consumers' views ebbed a bit in July, with the University of Michigan's initial estimate on its Consumer Sentiment Index easing to 93.3. That was a wide step down from June's 96.1 tally, undercutting expectations for 96.
A big rollout of second-quarter earnings reports imposed a mixed effect on early trade.
General Electric (GE) and Schlumberger (SLB) rose a fraction each. Sweden-based telecom giant Ericsson (ERIC) climbed nearly 4%. Mattel (MAT) and Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) each shed more than 2%.

Google surged 14% out of the gate, as mobile search products led a broad advance in company revenue. Second-quarter results showed earnings and revenue topping analyst consensus views. Cost increases slowed. So did paid ad clicks, rising 18%, vs. a 25% increase during the same period last year. Watch time at Google's YouTube unit swelled 60% during the quarter, its fastest growth in two years. The gain left shares at a new high and 17% above a 584.80 buy point in a flat base.
A number of China-based stocks were hammering out strong early moves after a positive week for recently hard-hit markets in China. Baidu (BIDU) swept up more than 3%. Noah (NOAH) rose 2%.

Railroad Kansas City Southern (KSU) pared some early gains, but remained up 5% after reporting mixed Q2 results. Earnings narrowly topped forecasts, but revenue fell 10% — more than expected. S&P Capital IQ trimmed the stock's price target to 120, from 143, but kept its buy rating. The move put Kansas City back above its 10-week moving average, but the stock has been unwinding since November.

Two in every five IBD 50 stocks gained at the open. Facebook topped the list, jumping 3% to a new high. The stock is a bit shy of 9% past a flat-base buy point of 86.17. Stocks took a turn for the worst in the closing hours of Wednesday's session after talks in Brussels ended with a deal on Greek debt appearing no closer.

The major indexes finished at their lows in the stock market today. The Nasdaq and the S&P; 500 each lost 0.7% and the Dow Jones industrial average was down 1%. Volume was higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq exchange, according to preliminary data.
Only four stocks in the IBD 50 list of top-performing growth stocks were up or flat for the day. Autohome (ATHM) gained nearly 4% as it builds the right side of a long, deep consolidation.
Netflix (NFLX), which surged almost 4% in the morning on news of a pending 7-for-1 stock split, reversed to finish down 0.4% in heavy volume.
Before Thursday's open, the Labor Department is forecast to report jobless claims for the week June 20 of 273,000 compared to 267,000 the prior week.

Stocks climbed Tuesday to extend a weeklong rebound and remove some more gloom from the market. The Nasdaq led with a 0.7% advance. Biotechs were a source of strength on the composite index for a third straight day. The S&P 500 climbed 0.4%, aided largely by an energy sector that rallied despite an international agreement that eventually lets Iran put…

Rather than the start of a downward spiral, the stock market is in "the middle of what could be the longest U.S. expansion ever," says Adam Parker, Morgan Stanley's chief U.S. equity strategist, who lists 27 stocks to buy amid the volatility. In a report published Friday, Parker said recent swings should be viewed as a "temporary setback, not the…

Major U.S. ETFs clawed back from early losses Monday with positive homebuilder data giving stocks a boost. Stock ETFs hobbled out of the starting gate amid surprisingly weak New York manufacturing data.
Exchange traded funds holding homebuilder stocks hit 52-week highs as the key Housing Market Index, a gauge of builder sentiment, recorded its highest level since November 2005.
They led sector equity ETFs higher, along with biotechs and precious metal miners. Financials and consumer staples crowded the tail end.

IShares U.S. Home Construction (ITB) and SPDR S&P Homebuilders (XHB) rose about 1% each. In the past year, ITB has gained 24% and XHB 23%. By comparison, SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), a proxy for the broad market, is up 6%.
Both ETFs are concentrated bets on an extremely narrow segment of the market. But homebuilder stocks are gaining momentum. Home sales are getting a boost from demographics and improving job numbers.

D.R. Horton (DHI), which IBD ranks No. 1 in the residential-commercial building group, popped 2% in early afternoon trade. It's the top holding in ITB, with 12% of assets. Other top five holdings — Lennar (LEN), PulteGroup (PHM), Toll Brothers (TOL) and NVR (NVR) — also rose roughly 1% to 2% each.
ITB holds $2.31 billion in assets and 41 stocks. It has a 0.45% expense ratio, or $45 in annual fees for every $10,000 invested.
Homebuilders account for nearly two-thirds of ITB's total assets. The ETF also has big stakes in producers of building materials and fixtures, home improvement stores and furniture companies.
Among other top 10 holdings in ITB, Home Depot (HD) and Lowe's (LOW) report quarterly results Tuesday and Wednesday, respectively. Both retailers rose fractionally on the stock market today.
Homebuilder ETFs tend to be volatile, cautions Morningstar analyst Robert Goldsborough.

"The housing sector is highly cyclical and quite sensitive to economic and credit conditions," he writes. As such, he suggests these ETFs are "suitable only as a complementary satellite holding in a diversified portfolio."
XHB gives equal weight to its 36 stock holdings. It has $1.94 billion in assets and a 0.35% expense ratio.
Oil prices traded at multiyear lows before trimming losses.
China A-share ETFs led their international peers higher. The China Shanghai Composite index ended Monday's trading session higher, with airlines in the lead. The Hong Kong index fell 0.7%.
Here's a look at how benchmark exchange traded funds tracking various asset classes are performing today.
Following daily ETF market action can be key to successful investing:

The market also appeared to telegraph some nervousness over the Supreme Court's pending decision over whether ObamaCare's federal subsidy program runs afoul of the Constitution. The economy rose at a 2% annual rate in the third quarter, revised down from 2.1% and Q2's 3.9%, the Commerce Department said Tuesday. The U.S. is on pace for a 10th straight year of failing to achieve 3% annual growth. That helps explain why it took nearly a decade for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, and why Donald Trump has had so much support in his presidential run.

In the third quarter, exports were a little weaker than previously estimated, as U.S. manufacturers and others struggle to sell to weak overseas economies amid a strong dollar. Inventories rose a little less than expected, subtracting 0.7 percentage point from Q3 GDP growth. Most economists expect business destockpiling still has a ways to go.

Business investment rose at a 9.9% pace, the best in a year. Consumer spending, which accounts for roughly 70% of economic activity, rose at a solid 3% pace amid improving jobs and wages and cheap gas prices at the pump.

But through the first nine months of 2015, GDP has risen at a 2.2% rate. Most economists see Q4 growth as lackluster, leaving the economy with less than 3% yet again. This decade of futility would the worst in the post-World War II era.

Sluggish growth has left wages stagnant for Americans, especially noncollege educated men. This blue collar discontent has generated resentment and forms the base of Trump's populist presidential run. More than two-thirds (69%) of Trump supporters say the U.S. is still in a recession, according to the latest IBD/TIPP Poll, even though the current expansion started in June 2009; 44% of Trump supporters are in job-sensitive households, meaning they or someone in their family are looking for work or worried about losing their job.

The decade of weak economic growth — including the sharpest recession since the Depression and the weakest expansion since WWII — also lines up with the Fed's reluctance to raise rates. Until this month's move, the Fed hadn't hiked since mid-2006, and for nearly 7 years the rate had been near zero.
Job growth has been sluggish and wages too. Yes, unemployment has fallen to 5%, but much of that reflects a sharp decline in the labor force participation rate.
Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen and other policymakers have stressed that future tightening will be gradual, if not glacial.
In other economic news:
Existing-home sales plunge

Existing-home sales fell 10.5% in November to an annual rate of 4.76 million units, the National Association of Realtors said, the slowest pace in 19 months and much worse than expected. Existing-home sales fell 3.8% vs. a year earlier. The median price rose 6.3% vs. a year earlier to $220,300. New mortgage disclosure rules appeared to delay existing-home closings, perhaps pushing some closings into November.

NAR also once again blamed a lack of supply for the weak housing sales figures. The number of existing homes for sales fell 3.3% to 2.04 million — down 1.9% vs. a year earlier. Tight supply and rising home prices should spur more activity from D.R. Horton (DHI), Lennar (LEN) and other homebuilders. Housing starts have not risen particularly fast, but did jump in November, with single-family starts and permits hitting their best levels in nearly eight years. Shares of D.R. Horton and Lennar rose in afternoon trading Tuesday.

 The FHFA House Price Index rose 0.5% in October and 6.1% vs. a year earlier. The Federal Housing Finance Agency's index covers single-family housing, using data provided by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
U.S., Brent crude hit parity

U.S. crude futures and London-based Brent crude futures are now virtually the same, following Fri.'s end of the 40-year U.S. oil export ban. U.S. crude rose 1.2%, or 43 cents, to $36.23 a barrel intraday. Brent crude fell 7 cents to $36.28 after undercutting U.S. oil prices intraday. The U.S. shale boom meant bulging supplies in America. That benefitted refiners like Valero Energy (VLO), but meant lower prices for U.S. producers such as Continental Resources (CLR).
 China's leading economic index rose 0.6% after climbing 0.3% in October.
 German import prices fell 0.2% in November after falling 0.3% in October. Prices slid 3.5% vs. a year earlier, a smaller drop than October's 4.1% fall.
 German consumer confidence rose, according to the forward-looking GfK Consumer Climate. It ticked up to 9.4 in January vs. expectations of no change from December's 9.3.

(CCL), Lennar (LEN) and Cintas (CTAS).Accenture reports before the open on Thursday. Analysts expect earnings to edge up 2%, while revenue rises a fraction. The stock is now about 2% below a 109.96 buy point from a flat base. Accenture has risen 20% this year.Carnival Corp. has gained 14% this year. Shares climbed above the 50-day line in average volume, and are now about 5% below a flat base buy point of 54.69. The cruise line is up 15% in 2015.Carnival reports fourth-quarter earnings on Friday morning. Earnings are projected to jump 52%, up from an 11% rise last quarter. Revenue is expected to fall a fraction.Carnival has a 70 Composite Rating, while Lennar has a 90 Composite Rating.Lennar is expected to see its fourth straight quarter of decelerating earnings growth, with the bottom-line projected to increase 5%. Revenue is seen rising 16%. The homebuilder will release its fourth-quarter results before the open on Friday.Lennar is trading about 11% below a buy point from a four-month-long consolidation pattern. The stock is up 11% this year.Cintas also earns a Composite Rating of 90. Stocks were down in huge volume Friday as the major averages remained volatile two days after the Fed raised interest rates for the first time in nearly a decade.

The Dow Jones industrial average slumped 1.1% while the S&P 500 dropped 0.9% and the Nasdaq lost 0.6%. Volume was sharply higher across the board in the stock market today due to options and futures expirations.

Disney (DIS) fell nearly 3% after BTIG downgraded the stock to sell on concerns that strong profits from Star Wars will be eclipsed by weak results in the company's cable business. The stock sliced through its 200-day moving average and was 11% off its 52-week high.

CarMax (KMX) plunged 9% in massive volume after the auto retailer posted a 5% increase in profit for the latest quarter, the smallest increase in five quarters and well below Wall Street estimates. Sales rose 4% to $3.5 billion, also below views. The stock is at its lowest level since October last year.

HomebuilderLennar (LEN) reversed and was down more than 2% as better-than-expected Q4 profit was tempered by revenue that was just below forecasts. The stock is below its 50-day and 200-day lines amid a consolidation that began in August.

On the upside, cruise line operator Carnival (CCL) was up nearly 4% after reporting better-than-expected fiscal Q4 results, with revenue and guidance in line with expectations. The stock retook its 50-day line as it works on a flat base. Rival Royal Caribbean (RCL) rose 2% and also retook its 50-day line as it shapes a late-stage flat base.

Stock futures narrowed early losses abruptly approaching the starting bell on Friday, while overseas markets continued to trade lower. Dow futures showed an 83.8-point decline, vs. a 153.8-point tumble an hour earlier.

Nasdaq 100 futures halved their hour-earlier loss to trade 17 points below fair market value. S&P 500 futures were 12.3 points lower, improved from a 20-point loss. Small caps remained under pressure, although Russell 2000 futures eased from their early loss to a 7.8-point decline.

The stock market today gets rolling with the S&P 500 below its converged 50- and 200-day moving averages and the Nasdaq below its 50-day line only. The market posted three days of healthy gains through Wednesday, which also included the Federal Reserve's launch of an interest rate tightening cycle. That's big news, and a big hurdle for the market to clear.

While Friday's premarket action was not encouraging, the Nasdaq does open the session with a 1.4% gain for the week, the S&P 500 is ahead 1.5%, and both indexes have gained in nine of the past 11 weeks.

The economic calendar closes out the week on a quiet note, with only the preliminary reading on U.S. services due out from researcher Markit at 9:45 a.m. ET, and regional surveys expected from the Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank at 10 a.m. and from the Kansas City Federal Reserve at 11 a.m. Baker Hughes (BHI) releases its weekly rig count data at 1 pm.

About half of the Dow's 30 stocks moved lower, the other half remained flat in premarket trade. Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), Boeing (BA) and Chevron (CVX) dipped more than 1%. DuPont (DD) was the sole gainer, up 0.6%.
Several late-season earnings reports whipped up some action before the bell.

CarMax (KMX) dived 13% before the open, after reporting its third-quarter sales and earnings stopped short of analysts estimates. Same-store-sales rose 0.8%, vs. expectations for a 2% increase. The stock has been scooping out a consolidation in tight trade since June.

Homebuilder Lennar (LEN) rose more than 1% as its fiscal Q4 earnings easily beat consensus views. Revenue growth stopped just short of forecasts, but new home deliveries rose 10% and orders for even newer homes jumped 20%. Lennar shares have been in a gradually weakening consolidation since August.
Handheld device maker BlackBerry (BBRY) grabbed a 6% gain. The Ontario, Canada, firm reported not-as-bad-as-expected Q3 sales and losses.

Among leaders, open source software developer Red Hat (RHT) jumped more than 6% to lead the IBD 50 list. The Raleigh, N.C., company late Thursday delivered Q3 revenue and earnings above consensus forecasts. Management's Q4 revenue guidance was above, earnings guidance was below, analyst consensus views. The stock has been working to retake its 50-day moving average, and ended Thursday 3% below an 81.59 cup-base buy point.

Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) climbed almost 2% after finally inking a deal to be taken private by a group of investors led by company chairman Zhou Hongyi for $9.3 billion. Zhou had proposed the deal earlier in the year, before markets in China slumped into a serious correction.

Oil prices slipped — West Texas Intermediate crude shed more than 1% to below $35 a barrel and down just over 3% for the week. Brent crude was a fraction lower, just below $37 and down almost 3% on the week. Gold rose a fraction, still standing tight near the $1,055 per ounce level. Copper futures popped 3%, leaving prices effectively level for the week.

Overseas, markets were broadly lower Friday but trading higher for the week. Japan's Nikkei 225 in Tokyo toppled 1.9%, leaving the index with a 1.3% loss for the week. The Shanghai Composite ended flat Friday and up 4.2% on the week. Hong Kong's Hang Seng ended Friday down 0.5%, but with a weekly gain of 1.4%.

In Europe, stocks were under pressure near midday — the Cac-40 in Paris was off 1.3%. Frankfurt's DAX dipped 0.8% and London's FTSE 100 showed a 0.7% decline. For the week, the FTSE 100 tracked toward a 1.9% gain, the Cac-40 was up 1.5% and the DAX showed a 3% gain.Stock futures narrowed early losses abruptly approaching the starting bell on Friday, while overseas markets continued to trade lower. Dow futures showed an 83.8-point decline, vs. a 153.8-point tumble an hour earlier. Nasdaq 100 futures halved their hour-earlier loss to trade 17 points below fair market value. Homebuilder stocks rose Monday as more first-time homebuyers moved off of the sidelines and jumped into the housing market in May. That helped to drive the biggest increase in existing home sales in nearly six years, according to a report from the National Association of Realtors out Monday. Total existing-home sales, which are completed transactions that include single-family homes, townhomes,…

While the housing market is still far from recovered, signs are increasingly pointing to stronger days ahead — even as mortgage rates, which moved above 4% last week, are expected to rise further. The economy picked up steam in the second quarter, jobs are growing, distressed inventory is dwindling, and building permits jumped in May, offsetting the fall in new-home…

The Mortgage Bankers Association's weekly survey rose 8.4% in the June 5 week, snapping a 6-week losing streak. Purchases surged 10% and were 25% higher than a year ago - good news for the housing market. Refinance applications also jumped, even though rates rose 15 basis points to 4.17% to the highest since November. Treasury yields have continued to rise…

The pace of new home sales slid in June to an annual 482,000, well below expectations and down 7% from May. But sales are up 18% vs. a year ago, and smoothing out the volatile data with a 3-month moving average shows them regaining strength after several lean years. Still, all signs point to go for housing, and new home…

All four U.S. national wireless firms will hook up with pay-TV partners, either in M&A or partnerships, says Oppenheimer, which says Comcast or Charter Communications looms as a buyer of the company T-Mobile US.

"We see Comcast (CMCSA) (with TMUS and partnering with other cable companies), AT&T (T), Verizon Communications (VZ), and Sprint (S)the four likely surviving companies," said Oppenheimer analyst Tim Horan in a research report.
Horan says there's only a 10% chance that Dish Network (DISH) buys T-Mobile (TMUS), which is controlled by Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY).
AT&T, which acquired DirecTV Group in late July, last week said its product-bundling plans could force Comcast to make a wireless acquisition.
Comcast, however, wasn't interested in T-Mobile earlier this year, according to industry sources.
Sprint's owner, Japan-based SoftBank, reportedly explored a sale of money-losing Sprint to Comcast and France's Altice, but talks "went nowhere," according to a report.
"Regardless, of the timing, we expect all four wireless carriers to align with a paid TV provider in some form," wrote Horan.
If Comcast does not pursue a deal, Charter Communications (CHTR) could, speculates Horan. Charter is seeking approval to buy Time Warner Cable (TWC).
Like Comcast, Charter has been expanding a public Wi-Fi network.
Who Wants Dish's Spectrum?

Horan opines that Verizon is the only "real" potential buyer of Dish Network's radio spectrum, but says Verizon "won't pay a premium for it." JPMorgan last year said a partnership structure between Verizon and Dish Network made sense, though it could take time for a deal to jell.
Meanwhile, existing-home sales rose to an eight-year high in July, but millennials were still missing in action as the share of first-time buyers fell to the lowest since January.
Existing-home sales surged to a stronger-than-expected 5.59 million annual rate, up 10.3% vs. a year earlier.
Inventories are lean — the current supply is 4.8 months' worth. That's been pushing up prices, though they cooled by 1% in July.
However, first-timers fell to 28% of the total in July, the lowest since January. That's down from 30% in June and May's 32%, the strongest since 2012.

Many homebuilders catering to first-time and millennial buyers have fared well, with shares of D.R. Horton (DHI), LGI Homes (LGIH) and Lennar (LEN) hitting longtime or record highs over the past week, though so has luxury builder Toll Bros. (TOL)
Horton pulled back in mild fashion on Thursday, falling less than 2% in slightly above-average trade. The stock is up 10% past a 28.80 cup-with-handle entry.

LGI dropped 5% in heavy trade, but remains sharply above a 20.20 base buy point. A pair of homebuilder companies reported mixed results for their second quarters Thursday, sending shares of one up slightly and the other down, while bigger names in the industry group also fell.

PulteGroup (PHM), the No. 3 builder by market cap, rose less than 1% in afternoon trading after it beat earnings views by 2 cents per share on revenue of $1.2 billion, which was about flat from the earlier year and below the $1.37 billion analysts had expected.

But investors apparently forgave the revenue miss in favor of a more forward-looking report on the value of net new orders, which jumped 11% to $1.8 billion on a 7% gain in unit numbers, to 5,118 homes.
PulteGroup's CEO Richard Dugas noted that the value of new orders was the highest in a quarter since 2007.

Smaller builder M/I Homes (MHO) also beat views by two cents, with earnings per share coming in at 43 cents, up from 31 cents a year earlier. Homes delivered in the quarter rose 3% to 919 homes, while new contracts increased 8% to 1,100 homes. But investors didn't cheer, sending the stock down more than 2%.

Shares of PulteGroup and M/I Homes are nearly flat from where they started the year. Neither one is ranked highly by IBD, which gives PulteGroup a low 54 Composite Rating out of 99 possible and M/I a somewhat better score of 69.

Shares of better-ranked Lennar (LEN) and D.R. Horton (DHI), the No. 1 and No. 2 homebuilders by market cap, were down more than 1% in afternoon trading.A pair of homebuilder companies reported mixed results for their second quarters Thursday, sending shares of one up slightly and the other down, while bigger names in the industry group also fell.PulteGroup (PHM), the No. 3 builder by market cap, rose less than 1% in afternoon trading after it beat earnings views by 2 cents per share on revenue of $1.2 billion, which was about flat from the earlier year and below the $1.37 billion analysts had expected.But investors apparently forgave the revenue miss in favor of a more forward-looking report on the value of net new orders, which jumped 11% to $1.8 billion on a 7% gain in unit numbers, to 5,118 homes.PulteGroup's CEO Richard Dugas noted that the value of new orders was the highest in a quarter since 2007.Smaller builder M/I Homes (MHO) also beat views by two cents, with earnings per share coming in at 43 cents, up from 31 cents a year earlier. The S&P; 500 suffered another mild distribution day Tuesday, and semiconductor stocks weighed on the Nasdaq. But it wasn't all bad for the broad market despite another sell-off in China stocks overnight. The Nasdaq fell 0.6%, the S&P; 500 eased 0.3%, and the Dow gave up 0.2%. Ironically, selling wasn't intense on the S&P; 500, but higher volume still resulted…

Housing starts rebounded in November, with single-family starts the best in nearly eight years, the Commerce Department said Wednesday. Homebuilder stocks such as D.R. Horton (DHI), Lennar (LEN) and LGI Homes (LGIH) rallied into and after the Federal Reserve rate hike on Wednesday.

Builders broke ground on an annualized 1.173 million units last month, up 10.5% vs. October, when starts tumbled 12%. Single-family new construction climbed 7.6% to an annualized 768,000, the most since December 2007 when the last recession started. Construction on apartments and other dwellings with five or more units shot up 18.1% after diving 25.9% in October. Lennar is among the homebuilders that has been active in apartments.
Building permits, a signal of future activity, jumped 11% after October's 5.1% gain, hitting a five-month high. Single-family permits rose 1.1%, also their best since December 2007.

Homebuilders have been cautious about stepping up activity, even amid an improving economy and tight housing supply. The report is a sign that they are becoming a little bolder, even as the Fed prepared to raise interest rates.

Markets seem to have priced in an initial hike into mortgage rates, and Fed chief Janet Yellen again said the Fed would be be very gradual about further tightening. If job gains continue, especially among millennials, housing demand should be solid going forward.

D.R. Horton, Lennar and KB Home (KBH) all rose about 2% each in afternoon trade on the stock market today. LGI Homes and PulteGroup (PHM) climbed about 3% apiece intraday. PulteGroup announced Wednesday that it plans to pay $430 million to $450 million for assets of John Wieland Homes & Neighborhoods, a builder of move-up and luxury houses in the Southeast.

Stocks got off to a strong start Tuesday, as oil prices took a modest bounce and European markets rallied. The S&P 500 and the Nasdaq each jumped 1.3%. The Dow pulled a 1.1% gain.
Volume upshifted 19% on the Nasdaq and 17% on the NYSE, relative to action at the same time Monday.
The stock market today opened to lukewarm economic news: November consumer prices were in line with expectations. Manufacturing in the New York region slowed less than expected.

Confidence among building contractors faded just a bit this month, with the Housing Market Index from the National Association of Home Builders easing to 61, down from 62 in November and below views for an uptick to 63. Homebuilding stocks seemed unaffected, with D.R. Horton (DHI), Lennar (LEN) and Toll Brothers (TOL) all up more than 1%.
Oil prices held their early gains, up a bit more than 1%. West Texas Intermediate crude undercut a December 2008 low on Monday, marking its weakest price since April 2004.

Diversified operator 3M (MMM) shed more than 4% after lowering its 2015 EPS guidance. The loss took the low post on both the Dow and the S&P 500. Chevron (CVX) and Exxon-Mobil (XOM) topped the Dow, up more than 2.5% each.

Coal miner Consol Energy (CNX) and natural gas producer Southwestern Energy (SWN) were up more than 5% each at one point, duking it out for top billing among S&P 500 stocks. Drugmaker Mallinckrodt (MNK) was also in the running, up nearly 6% early in the session.

Satellite radio broadcaster Sirius XM (SIRI) jumped nearly 4% to the head of the Nasdaq 100. Aging radio shock jock Howard Stern announced plans to retire under a 12-year agreement with Sirius, under which he will produce his popular radio show for the next five years. The deal includes Sirius' use of Stern's audio and video library.
Imax (IMAX) battered out the top gain among IBD 50 stocks, up nearly 5% in heavy trade. The move sent shares to just below a 39.97 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Overseas, Europe's market continued to build on early gains, with Frankfurt's DAX and the CAC-40 in Paris up well over 3% in afternoon trade.Stocks got off to a strong start Tuesday, as oil prices took a modest bounce and European markets rallied. Stocks pared gains at midday Wednesday amid expectations the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later in the day. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq were each up 0.2% while the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.1%.
Volume on the Nasdaq and the NYSE were tracking below Tuesday's levels.
Fed policymakers are expected to raise interest rates by 25 basis points, marking the first increase since the central bank dropped rates to near zero in 2008 amid the financial crisis.
In the stock market today, drugmaker Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) jumped 7% in heavy volume despite issuing a weaker-than-expected 2016 earnings forecast.

The stock jumped 16% Tuesday after announcing a distribution agreement with Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA), which the Canada-based drugmaker said would help rebuild its business after it cut ties with Philidor Rx Services amid allegations of wrongdoing. However, Valeant's forecast for a 30% jump in 2016 profit fell short of analysts' expectations.
Solar stocks were among the day's best performers, led by First Solar (FSLR), which jumped 8% to a new high in heavy volume.

Makers of solar panels and components have gotten a lift after negotiators from the U.S. and nearly 200 other countries reached a deal last weekend to cut greenhouse gas emissions. The agreement could lead to greater investment in energy efficient solar technologies like solar.

On the downside, Global Payments (GPN) plunged 10% in heavy volume, slicing through its 50-day line, after the credit card payments processor said it would buy rival Heartland Payment Systems (HPY) for $4.3 billion.

Meanwhile, homebuiders rose after housing starts and building permits rose much more than expected in November, according to data from the Commerce Department. That sent homebuilders Pulte Group (PHM) and Toll Bros. (TOL) each up 2%, while D.R. Horton (DHI) and Lennar (LEN) both rose about 1%.Stocks pared gains at midday Wednesday amid expectations the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later in the day. Loan applications for buying a home are at their best levels since 2010, but shares of homebuilders such as D.R. Horton (DHI), Lennar (LEN), KB Home (KBH) and LGI Homes (LGIH) retreated Wednesday afternoon. The mortgage applications index rose 1.2% in the week ended Dec. 4, the Mortgage Bankers Association said Wednesday. Refinancing activity advanced 3%, but that's after bigger…

With the housing market still working on its multiyear recovery, the homebuilder industry — measured by some two dozen homebuilders tracked by Investor's Business Daily — has gained 21% year-to-date through Friday. But it's been a shaky ride. On Tuesday, share prices in the group fell nearly in unison after luxury builder Toll Bros. (TOL) missed analyst-consensus earnings views with…

A key factory activity index returned to positive territory, while jobless claims edged lower. But Americans' confidence remains lackluster.Philly Fed manufacturing index signals growthThe Philadelphia Federal Reserve's manufacturing index for the mid-Atlantic district rose to 1.9 in November from -4.5 in October and -6 in September. Economists had expected a reading of -0.5, just below break-even. New orders, shipments and work hours remained negative, but employment turned positive and so did unfilled orders, which have been negative for most of the year. Manufacturers also were more upbeat. Manufacturing has been sluggish, with employment falling due to energy sector woes and overseas weakness. But manufacturing output was strong in the October industrial production report.Jobless claims stay near lowsInitial claims for state unemployment benefits fell by 5,000 in the week ended Nov. 14 to 271,000, the Labor Department said. That's near a 42-year low. Claims have stayed below 300,000 for 37 straight weeks. Claims below 300,000 are usually tied to robust job growth. But October's strong report aside, net hiring has generally been modest.The four-week moving average of claims rose 3,000 to 270,750 last week. The number of people continuing to claim benefits rose by 2,000 to 2.18 million in the week ended Nov. 7.October home sales weakOctober home sales were flat vs. a year earlier, a "dramatic" downshift from September's double-digit gain, according to Redfin, a national real estate brokerage. Twenty-seven of 67 metros tracked by Redfin had fewer transactions, including Seattle, Denver, Miami, Dallas and Austin, Texas, which have among the strongest housing markets. Southern California home sales fell 5.5% vs. September and rose just 1% vs. a year earlier, according to CoreLogic.Tight supply is a problem. Homebuilders such as D.R. Horton (DHI) and Lennar (LEN) have not been ramping up construction — October housing starts dived 11% amid labor and land shortages.Americans hold low view of economyOne in five Americans in November said the economy is improving, matching the smallest share in two years, according to data from the Bloomberg Consumer Comfort Index. The economic outlook gauge edged up to 42.5 from October's 42, which was the worst since September 2014. The weekly overall sentiment gauge dipped 0.4 point to 41.2 in the period ended Nov. 15. Confidence among full-time workers was the worst in a year. That follows October's strong payroll and wage report, but that followed weak hiring in August and September.LEI jumps on yield spread, stocksThe Index of Leading Economic Indicators rose 0.6% in October after falling 0.1% in September and 0.1% in August, the Conference Board said. A wider yield spread, stronger stock prices and higher building permits led the way. "Despite lackluster third-quarter growth, the economic outlook now appears to be improving," said Ataman Ozyildirim, director of Business Cycles & Growth Research at the Conference Board.Bank of Japan stands pat in recessionThe Bank of Japan, as expected, continued to boost its balance sheet by buying government bonds and riskier assets at an annual rate of 80 trillion yen ($650 billion). It still is betting that the economy is ready to rebound, days after the gov't reported that the country fell into a recession yet again, contracting modestly in Q2 and Q3. Capital spending is weak and global conditions tricky.Japan department store sales solidThey rose 4.2% in October vs. a year earlier after decelerating for three straight months to a 1.8% gain. Many store sales, especially in Tokyo, are to tourists. Chinese trips to Japan has boomed as a travel-hungry Chinese middle class take advantage of eased visa rules.

The stock market got off to a rough start Tuesday, falling hard in the morning, but major averages recovered nicely into the close, perhaps helped by news the eurozone is considering a proposal for interim funding for Greece. After falling 1.8% early, the Nasdaq showed a gain of 0.1% by the close. For the S&P; 500, a 1.2% loss morphed…

Homebuilder shares surged in the wake of the proposed $5.2 billion merger of Standard Pacific (SPF) and Ryland Group (RYL) as speculation rises over additional consolidation in the industry.By early afternoon, the rising tide lifted the boats of Meritage Homes (MTH), whose shares were up 2.8% to 44.65 in the stock market today as volume rose 88%. MDC Holdings (MDC) stock rose 3.3% to 29.68 as volume lifted 217%. Lennar (LEN) shares were up 1% to 47.96, while KB Home (KBH) stock was up 0.5% to 14.99.The surging stocks come as homebuilder confidence hit a nine-month high, rising 5 points to 59, according to National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo data released Monday. Results greater than 50 signal that homebuilders are optimistic about sales. It was the 12th straight month of above-50 hopes.Despite the optimism, the housing sector's recovery has been sluggish since the recession ended in June 2009. Slow job and wage growth, young buyers burdened with student loans and restrictive mortgage standards have been cited for the sector's tepid recovery.Ryland CEO Larry Nicholson, who will serve as CEO and president of the yet-unnamed combined company, told the Wall Street Journal: "We expect to see slow, steady growth for the next couple of years."The Standard Pacific-Ryland deal would result in the two Southern California-based companies controlling 74,000 home sites.Follow Ciaran McEvoy on Twitter: @IBD_CMcEvoy.

Lower gas prices finally may be translating into people feeling a little more willing to open their wallets as analysts predict consumer discretionary companies to be leaders in the second quarter's earnings season. Consumer discretionary retailers, which comprise about 17% of the overall Standard & Poor's 500, are expected to deliver 7.2% earnings growth in Q2 compared to a year…

In a sign that more prospective homebuyers are moving off the sidelines, pending home sales rose to their highest level in nine years in April, according to a National Association of Realtors report Thursday. Led by the Northeast and Midwest, all four major regions saw increases in April. The Pending Home Sales Index, which is based on contract signings, increased…

The U.S. housing market is swinging away from investor cash purchases to more traditional homebuying and low down payment mortgages. But some spots remain cash-competition havens, including Florida and New York. Miami, with a lot of foreign money pouring in to buy condos, tops the list with 56% of homes paid for in cash. Tampa, Orlando and Jacksonville follow in…
Combining superior fundamentals with strong chart action can pinpoint top stock watch candidates such as Gilead Sciences.

Today's Screen Of The Day, Top Fundamentals, features highly rated firms with three-year sales and earnings growth rates of at least 25%, sorted by the biggest estimated earnings-per-share percentage change from a year ago.
The list includes three companies that also have the stability of size: drugmaker Gilead Sciences (GILD), online marketplace Alibaba Group (BABA) and homebuilder Lennar (LEN), large companies all.
Gilead Sciences

Silicon Valley-based biotech Gilead Sciences, with $27.5 billion in annual sales, has flourished by developing treatments for HIV and hepatitis. Its hepatitis C drugs Sovaldi and Harvoni accounted for more than half of its sales in a recent quarter.
But analysts say that sales of those blockbusters may be hitting a ceiling and that Gilead may go on the acquisition trail to find a hot new product.

Gilead will report second-quarter financial results after the market closes on July 28. Consensus is for EPS to rise a relatively mild 14% to $2.70 on a 16.5% hike in revenue to $7.61 billion. Gilead has beaten Wall Street estimates six of the last seven quarters.

Gilead was down fractionally in the stock market today (Wednesday). Gilead rose above a five-month, 26%-deep first-stage base with a 116.93 buy point on June 11, when it closed at 119.13. It may be forming a base-on-base cup-with-handle pattern.
Alibaba Group

Alibaba, Jack Ma's Chinese online marketplace, with $12.3 billion annual revenue, is growing rapidly by providing a service in China similar to Amazon.com (AMZN) in the U.S. Both companies are ramping up competition at the global level.

In June, for example, Alibaba's digital entertainment wing, Alibaba Pictures, said that it had invested in its first Hollywood film, "Mission: Impossible — Rogue Nation," set to open in theaters on July 31. The company also announced plans to launch a Netflix (NFLX)-type video streaming service in China.

On Wednesday, Alibaba's Aliyun cloud division published a "Data Protection Pact" designed to reassure potential cloud customers that their data are safe as it looks to take on Google (GOOGL), Microsoft (MSFT) and others in the cloud.
Alibaba has a 45% three-year EPS growth rate, and its quarterly sales have grown at an 87% rate during that time. Alibaba rose 2% Wednesday.
Lennar
Top-rated homebuilder Lennar, with $8.63 billion annual revenue, is trying to break out as the housing market shows continued signs of recovery. Its timing seems right.
The National Association of Realtors said Wednesday that existing home sales in June climbed nearly 10% from a year ago, better than expected.
Earlier in the month, the National Association of Home Builders sentiment index hit 60, matching the best levels going back to November 2005.

Lennar's three-year EPS growth rate is 32%, and its revenue growth rate is 75%. Its stock rose above a 52.60 cup-with-handle buy point on Wednesday's NAR report to close at 53.19, up 2.7% for the day. It's extended above its 50-day moving average and 10-week line.

Existing-home sales fell 3.4% in October to annual rate of 5.36 million, the National Association of Realtors said Monday, as the supply of properties for sale continues to dwindle. But so far that hasn't translated stronger activity from homebuilders such as D.R. Horton (DHI), KB Home (KBH), Lennar (LEN) and LGI Homes (LGIH). October's decline eased most of September's strong…
Stocks rolled out to moderate gains in quiet trade Wednesday, as global markets took an optimistic stance ahead of a dramatic decision from the Federal Reserve this afternoon.
The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 tacked on 0.5% gains. The Nasdaq nosed up 0.4%.
Volume was soft, down 18% on the NYSE and 22% lower on the Nasdaq, relative to action at the same time Tuesday.
The Fed's policy announcement at 2 p.m. ET and Janet Yellen's news conference set to follow at 2:30 are the big news items stirring the stock market today.

Housing starts and building permits rose much more than expected in November, according to early data from the Commerce Department. That sent homebuilders D.R. Horton (DHI), Lennar (LEN), Pulte Group (PHM) and Toll Bros. (TOL) up about 2%.

Manufacturing news was less good, with researcher Markit reporting its preliminary estimate on its Purchasing Managers' Index for December eased to 51.3, down from 52.6 in November and below consensus projections for 52.8.

U.S. industrial production slipped 0.6% in November, and the Federal Reserve revised October's decline lower to 0.4%. Economists had expected a 0.2% dip. Utilization of the capacity in those factories was 77% in November vs. 77.5% in October and below views for 77.4%.

Metals were up, oil was down, agricultural commodities were mixed. Overseas, Europe's markets added cautiously to early gains. London's FTSE 100 and the DAX in Frankfurt were ahead 1% each near midday. The CAC-40 in Paris showed a 0.8% gain.

Nearly half of the Dow's 30 stocks opened more than 1% higher. Walt Disney (DIS) led, up nearly 2% after announcing a content distribution deal with China's Alibaba (BABA). Alibaba shares rose more than 1%.
Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) dropped almost 1% apiece, the index's only losses.

Oil and natural gas producers were also at the bottom of the S&P 500: Southwestern Energy (SWN), Marathon Oil (MRO), Range Resources (RRC) and Noble Energy (NBL) were all down about 3%. Steel maker Nucor (NUE) was also down 3% after offering preliminary Q4 earnings guidance below consensus views.
Solar electrical components and systems maker First Solar (FSLR) surged to the top of the S&P 500 with an 8% advance. Frontier Communications (FTR) was next in line with a 5% gain.
More than 20% of the Nasdaq 100 stocks opened higher. Cognizant (CTSH) ran ahead, rising nearly 3%.
On the IBD 50 list, 40 stocks opened higher and a third of the group rose more than 1%.
Gun maker Smith & Wesson (SWHC) bounced 3% higher, taking back a portion of Tuesday's 10% tumble. The gain put shares 16% above a 19.07 buy point.

Refiner Tesoro (TSO) climbed almost 3% in strong trade. The stock is working on a third straight advance as it rebounds from a test of support at its 200-day moving average. The stock had dropped 7% below a 105.64 buy point after briefly clearing that buy marker in a cup-with-handle base. Investors may have opted to trip the 7% to 8% sell rule. Shares are now less than 1% from retaking the buy point.

Global Payments (GPN) trimmed some losses, but remained down 8% in heavy trade. The Atlanta-based payment processing outfit announced it would pay $4.3 billion to acquire peer Heartland Payment Systems (HPY). Global also reported slightly better than expected fiscal Q2 earnings and revenue growth of 5% — below analyst consensus forecasts. In Wednesday's IBD, the Building-Residential/Commercial industry group ranked No. 9 out of 197 groups, improving slightly from No. 12 three weeks ago. Six weeks ago, the group was at No. 7. Housing reports for the…

Single-family home and condo sales averaged almost 100% of their estimated full market value nationwide in April, signaling a nice balance between supply and demand, according to a RealtyTrac report out Thursday morning. But a few markets outpaced the pack with sale prices above their market value, including spots in California; the Washington, D.C., area; and the Winston-Salem, N.C., area.…

In a sign that more prospective homebuyers are moving off the sidelines, pending home sales rose to their highest level in nine years in April, according to a National Association of Realtors report Thursday. Led by the Northeast and Midwest, all four major regions saw increases in April. The Pending Home Sales Index, which is based on contract signings, increased…

Toll Bros. (TOL) stock fell after it reported lower-than-expected second-quarter sales Wednesday, despite an improving housing market. The luxury homebuilder's earnings rose 6% to 37 cents per share, 2 cents above consensus. Revenue fell 1% to $852.6 million, undershooting Wall Street's $861.2 million target, as deliveries slipped 2% to 1,195 units. "The economy and housing continue on parallel paths of…

Housing fumbled again, as existing-home sales dipped 3.3% in April following a string of better data. Sales were at an annual rate of 5.04 million units in April, the National Association of Realtors said. That followed a slightly upwardly-revised March tally of 5.21 million and was 6.1% higher than a year ago. It was the seventh-straight month of higher yearly tallies, NAR noted, suggesting March may have been a hard act to follow.Realtors see "elevated levels of buying interest compared to a year ago," NAR said, and pointed to tighter inventory as a culprit for lower sales. Total inventory was up 10% in April, but still lower than a year ago, and the 5.3 months of supply on the market is lower than the long-term average of 6 months' worth.That's pressuring prices upward as well: the median price of $219,400 was 8.9% higher than a year ago, and represented the biggest yearly gain in any month since January 2014. Good news for sellers, but more challenging for buyers.The mixed existing-home data left homebuilder stocks such as D.R. Horton (DHI), Lennar (LEN), PulteGroup (PHM) and KB Home (KBH) little changed Thursday afternoon. D.R. Horton and KB Home rose fractionally, while PulteGroup and Lennar fell about 0.5%.

Mortgage applications have been on quite a ride for the past two years. In May 2013, then-Fed President Bernanke noted that the central bank would eventually start to normalize monetary policy, which had left interest rates near zero for years. Mortgage interest rates shot up in just a few weeks, from about 3.7% to 4.7%, and there's some evidence that those higher rates quelled demand for housing for some time.

But rates drifted lower throughout 2014 as broader economic forces weighed on the market, such as stepped-up bond-buying and rate-cutting by other central banks. That provided some boost for refinancings, though analysts continue to believe that most homeowners who could refinance already have.
Applications for mortgage purchases ticked down in the MBA's latest weekly survey, but refinancing applications defied the odds and ticked up even as rates hit their highest level of the year, 4.04%.
On the other hand, applications for buying a home fell 3.7% after a 0.2% dip in the prior week.

Lennar (LEN), PulteGroup (PHM), KB Home (KBH) and D.R. Horton (DHI) fell modestly intraday in the stock market today after rallying Tuesday on booming housing starts.Mortgage applications have been on quite a ride for the past two years. Horton (DHI) fell modestly intraday in the stock market today after rallying Tuesday on booming housing starts.

Housing starts surge 20% Housing starts came in at an annual pace of 1.135 mil in April, the highest in more than 7 years and easily beating expectations. That followed a slightly upwardly revised March. Permits were also rosier than expected, at a 1.143 mil pace that was also the best in years. Homebuilder stocks, including Lennar (LEN), PulteGroup (PHM),…

The sentiment index from the National Association of Home Builders shed 2 points in May to touch 54. Analysts had expected a 1-point uptick to 57. That's 9 points above the level a year ago, NAHB pointed out; it's also the fourth monthly decline in 2015.Builders were more upbeat about the outlook for the next 6 months in May than about current conditions; the 6-month outlook gauge was 64, while the current conditions index was 59. Respondents have held tenaciously to bullish views, even as the housing rebound has failed to launch throughout the near-6 year recovery and in May alluded to "pent-up demand moving forward."But their perception of buyer traffic stumbled again in May. Traffic had been approaching the neutral 50 line late last year but in May sank deeper into contraction at 39.Still, Q1 was solid for many builders. Meritage (MTH) forecast a 25%-30% jump in revenue in 2015, and D.R. Horton (DHI) reported better-than-expected earnings, though some pressure on margins as its sales have been skewed toward entry-level homes. D.R. Horton, Meritage and Lennar (LEN) shares rose Monday.

The housing recovery appears to be moving from the slow lane to a somewhat faster lane as existing-home sales rise and builders step up new-home starts. Builders broke ground on more new homes in April — 20% more than in March, the fastest growth pace in more than seven years, portending potentially higher future sales for the likes of Lennar[ticker…
The share of U.S. home purchases paid in cash has fallen year-over-year since January 2013 to 37.9% in February of this year, as the number of foreclosed homes dwindles.
Cash is still king in Florida and Alabama, though, accounting for more than half of homebuying, according to a housing trends report from CoreLogic (CLGX).

In Florida's case, not only are there many foreclosed homes vs. most other states, but also South Florida sees a lot of purchases by international buyers. These purchases can skew toward cash, as can purchases of second homes and vacation homes, due to the difficulty of getting financing for them and to the use of such homes as investments.

CoreLogic noted in its report that cash sales' share peak occurred in January 2011, when cash transactions were 46.5% of home sales nationally, vs. an average of about 25% before the housing crisis. Due to seasonality, the report says, it's better to look at changes on a year-over-year basis than month-to-month.

Repossessed homes, or REOs (real estate owned by banks) accounted for about 60% of cash buys, followed by resales at around 38% and then short sales at just over 34%. Nearly 16% of new homes were paid for in cash, too.

Homebuilders Toll Bros. (TOL), PulteGroup (PHM) and Lennar (LEN) are among the companies that build homes in various vacation and resort spots that are popular places for second homes, among other locales.

If you're looking at which large metro areas have the most cash purchasing, head for Detroit or Miami, where it was 59% in February. Just behind those areas came the Fort Lauderdale and West Palm Beach areas of South Florida. Lowest on the list of big metro areas was Washington, D.C., where under 17% of homes were paid for in cash in February.
Follow Donna Howell on Twitter: @IBD_DHowell.

Whether you're looking to buy a new home or an existing one this spring, you'll likely find much the same thing just about everywhere: high demand, low supply, rising prices and heavy competition. That's the prognosis of U.S. housing experts as the spring homebuying season moves into its high gear. In most sections of the country, the combination of pent-up…
Stocks surrendered thin gains and slipped lower early Tuesday as investors contended with a rising dollar, sliding oil prices and mixed quarterly reports.
The Nasdaq was down 0.2%. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 dipped 0.1% each.
Volume swept higher, with Nasdaq trade rising 23% and NYSE volume up 18% vs. action at the same time Monday.

The Nasdaq drifted up to just below its April 27 high in the stock market today before pulling back to a flat stance. Oil prices dived nearly 2%. Gold trimmed more than 1%. Comments from European Central Bank officials that offered a clearer view into more-aggressive-than-expected ECB bond buying sent the euro sharply lower vs. the dollar. Eurozone markets soared, with the CAC-40 in Paris up 1.8% in afternoon trade. China's mainland markets also posted a very positive session, buoyed by the government's market reform plan. The Deutsche X-Trackers Harvest CSI 300 Fund (ASHR) surged more than 4%.

April housing starts jumped to an annualized rate of 1.135 million, up 20% from the Commerce Department's revised March estimate. It was the highest mark in more than seven years and the biggest percent gain since 1991, the department said. Lennar (LEN), DR Horton (DHI), Pulte Group (PHM) and Toll Bros. (TOL) all gained more than 1%.

Wal-Mart (WMT) gave the market wobbly knees, sliding more than 3% after both revenue and earnings missed analysts' first-quarter consensus projections. Sam's Club sales were weaker than expected, and currency exchange rates had some negative effect. Q2 earnings guidance was at the low end of analyst projections. The gap-down loss erased a three-session advance.

TJX (TJX) jumped nearly 3% in early trade, stepping to the front of the S&P 500 index. The owner of the Marshalls, Homegoods and TJ Maxx chains reported stronger-than-expected first-quarter sales and earnings. Management issued Q2 earnings guidance below analyst forecasts. The gap-up gain hoisted shares to within 3% of a 71.13 buy point in an eight-week flat base.

On the IBD 50 list, Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) muscled up more than 2% in very strong trade. The Woburn, Mass.-based chipmaker cleared a 102.87 buy point on Monday. It is still in buying range, not quite 3% above that pivot.

It was the highest mark in more than seven years and the biggest percent gain since 1991, the department said. Lennar (LEN), DR Horton (DHI), Pulte Group (PHM) and Toll Bros. (TOL) all gained more than 1%.Wal-Mart (WMT) gave the market wobbly knees, sliding more than 3% after both revenue and earnings missed analysts' first-quarter consensus projections. Sam's Club sales were weaker than expected, and currency exchange rates had some negative effect. Q2 earnings guidance was at the low end of analyst projections. The gap-down loss erased a three-session advance.TJX (TJX) jumped nearly 3% in early trade, stepping to the front of the S&P 500 index. The owner of the Marshalls, Homegoods and TJ Maxx chains reported stronger-than-expected first-quarter sales and earnings. Management issued Q2 earnings guidance below analyst forecasts. The gap-up gain hoisted shares to within 3% of a 71.13 buy point in an eight-week flat base.On the IBD 50 list, Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) muscled up more than 2% in very strong trade. The Woburn, Mass.-based chipmaker cleared a 102.87 buy point on Monday. It is still in buying range, not quite 3% above that pivot.After the close, AutoDesk (ADSK), Etsy (ETSY), Analog Devices (ADI) and Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) are among the many companies scheduled to report quarterly results.

Housing surprised to the upside for a change — and in a big way. April starts surged more than 20% to the highest since November 2007, and permits leapt 10% to the fastest since 2008. Both single-family and multifamily starts jumped by double-digits in the month, but single-family starts are up 15% vs. a year ago.Starts in the weather-battered Northeast offered some proof of the temporary factors that have been wreaking havoc with economic data in past months. They tumbled 57% from January to February, then rebounded 115% in March and 86% in April.Homebuilders have had a mixed spring. D.R. Horton (DHI) said orders jumped by nearly a third in Q1, but that margins could be pressured as entry-level homes make up a greater share of the total. Meritage (MTH) is forecasting revenue that's higher by as much as 25-20% in 2015, but PulteGroup (PHM) saw profit drop 26% in Q1. Builder confidence took a step back in April, the National Association of Home Builders said Monday, but sentiment remains relatively high, with builders particularly bullish about the next 6 months.Lennar (LEN), PulteGroup, KB Home (KBH), Meritage and D.R. Horton (DHI) rallied in the stock market today, but came off earlier highs as the market reversed.

Stocks were mixed heading into the final hour of trading Tuesday. Volume continued to track heavier across the board. The Dow Jones industrial average held on to a 0.1% gain, while the Nasdaq lost 0.1% and the S&P 500 dipped a fraction.

In economic news, April housing starts surged from March and topped consensus estimates. Homebuilders responded positively. Lennar (LEN), D.R. Horton (DHI) and NVR (NVR) added more than 1% each as they work on the right side of new base patterns.
Oil and gas groups were weak in the stock market today as crude plunged nearly 4%.
Among leading stocks, Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) added to Monday's breakout with a 2% gain. Shares are still in buy range past a 102.87 flat-base buy point.
Norwegian Cruise Line (NCLH) also added to a recent breakout past 55.48. Shares surged more than 3% but are still in range past the entry.

On the downside, Urban Outfitters (URBN) trimmed an 18% loss to 15%. Late Monday, the apparel retailer delivered disappointing Q1 earnings and sales. Oppenheimer, Piper Jaffray and JPMorgan all downgraded the stock Tuesday.

Noah Holdings (NOAH) tumbled 7% after touching an all-time high. The Chinese investment firm reported quarterly results after Monday's close. U.S. residential loan originations rose sharply in the first quarter, amid housing market hopes that more potential homebuyers would be sealing deals.
But the sharp increase during the quarter was driven by refinance originations, while purchase loan originations were up only slightly.
Loan originations for single-family homes and condos rose 17% from a year earlier to 1,551,865 loans, though they were down 6% from the prior quarter, according to a report from RealtyTrac Thursday.
The dollar volume of Q1 loan originations was up 32% from a year ago, to $377 billion, but down 1% from Q4, the report noted.
Refinance originations represented nearly $256 billion in Q1, or 67.8% of all loan origination dollar volume. Purchase loan originations represented $121 billion, or 32.2%.
As a share of total loan origination dollar volume, purchase originations reached a recent peak of 49.2% in Q2 2014, followed by three quarters of decreasing share.

"A dip in interest rates early in the year combined with lowered mortgage insurance premiums for FHA loans breathed some life back into the refinancing market in the first quarter," said Daren Blomquist, vice president at RealtyTrac, in a statement.

"The purchase loan market remained largely missing in action, despite tepid growth from a year ago," he added. "The prime buying season still remains ahead, providing some hope that first-time homebuyers and other traditional buyers relying on traditional financing will come out of the woodwork in greater numbers in the coming months."

As more first-time and traditional buyers move off the sidelines, it could aid builders who target some sales to first-time buyers.KB Home (KBH), Lennar (LEN), Meritage Homes (MTH) and PulteGroup (PHM) all build for several market segments.
Rising refi originations can bring homeowners funds for home improvement, good for stores Home Depot (HD) and Lowe's Cos. (LOW)

Of the nearly 1.6 million loan originations in Q1, 471,822 were purchase loan originations, down 25% from the prior quarter and up less than 1% from a year ago. There were 1,080,043 refinance originations in Q1, an increase of 6% from the prior quarter and 27% from a year ago.U.S. residential loan originations rose sharply in the first quarter, amid housing market hopes that more potential homebuyers would be sealing deals.But the sharp increase during the quarter was driven by refinance originations, while purchase loan originations were up only slightly.Loan originations for single-family homes and condos rose 17% from a year earlier to 1,551,865 loans, though they were down 6% from the prior quarter, according to a report from RealtyTrac Thursday.The dollar volume of Q1 loan originations was up 32% from a year ago, to $377 billion, but down 1% from Q4, the report noted.Refinance originations represented nearly $256 billion in Q1, or 67.8% of all loan origination dollar volume. U.S. existing-home prices rose 7.4% in Q1 vs. a year earlier, the third straight quarter of faster appreciation but below 2013's double-digit gains, the National Association of Realtors reported Monday. The median existing single-family home prices rose in 85% of U.S. major metro markets (148 out of 174) based on closings in Q1 vs. a year earlier. Fifty-one metro areas…

Vacation-home demand has been on a steady climb as a strong stock market, low interest rates and tempting deals have prompted high-end households to spend more freely on second residences and summer getaways.
The push comes as more high-net-worth buyers have opted to put some of the earnings they've gained from a rising stock market into second homes in spots that support a more leisure lifestyle.
Contributing to the increased demand are baby boomers home shopping for a place to vacation now, and retire to later.
Real estate brokers in resort locales from Massachusetts' Cape Cod to Nevada's Lake Tahoe report brisk second-home buying activity during the year's first quarter.
And real estate experts say the vacation home market is heating up.
"It's a very good time for vacation homes," Daren Blomquist, vice president at RealtyTrac told IBD. "They're a hot commodity now."
The reasons? Home prices are still "undervalued" in a lot areas, which are still coming back from the recession, he adds, citing parts of Florida as an example.
Deals From Coast To Desert

Blomquist says other areas where buyers can find some good deals are parts of New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts and Nevada, where foreclosures are still rising. They include vacation-home spots like Cape Cod and Las Vegas.

"The common thread (on the buying side) is this recovery is really benefiting people, who were conservative and careful with money during the last housing bubble and now have to ability to buy in a market with much tighter lending standards," Blomquist adds. "This recovery is about buyers with an investor mindset and with cash. Those people are willing to extend their real estate investment with a vacation home."
Adds Morningstar analyst James Krapfel: "Conditions are favorable for more second-home demand.

"More baby boomers are aging into their retirement years and we've had fairly strong equity markets. Also, the prices of their primary homes have gone up significantly in the past couple of years, which gives them more confidence to invest in a second home."
The trend bodes well for homebuilders such as Toll Bros. (TOL), PulteGroup (PHM) and Lennar (LEN), which build homes in various vacation and resort spots.

Nationwide, sales of homes intended for vacation use surged 57.4% last year to an estimated 1.13 million properties, according to the National Association of Realtors investment-and vacation-home buyers survey. It was the highest amount since NAR began the survey in 2003.
Vacation-home sales accounted for 21% of all transactions in 2014, their highest market share since the survey was first conducted.

Jessica Lautz, director of survey research and communications for the NAR, says one driver of the increase is the strong growth in the stock market last year, which has allowed buyers to take some of the gains they earned and invest in a vacation home.
Another driver is the fact that baby boomers are nearing retirement and one in five of vacation-property buyers surveyed plan to live in their homes when they retire.
Where Is Demand Strong?

Luxury homebuilder Toll Bros. builds homes in a number of vacation and resort areas. It has a big presence in Florida, where it builds homes in cities such as Orlando, Naples and Palm Beach, says Frederick Cooper, senior vice president of finance. It also builds homes in locales such as metro Denver in Colorado; Phoenix and Scottsdale in Arizona; and Reno and Las Vegas in Nevada.

"Over the past couple of years, but very much this year we've seen strong demand in the markets where people buy vacation homes, with particular strength in the Denver area, Florida and Reno this year," Cooper told IBD.

In some cases the robust demand is being driven by demographics where baby boomers want to have two homes, he adds, and in some other cases it's being driven by the strength in the stock market and "the solid position of the affluent customer."
He says prices vary from market to market. But in markets where there is "solid demand there is pricing power."

Out West, the Tahoe market has had a "very busy and exciting first quarter, and the second quarter is starting off strong," said Pamela Francis, a real estate broker at Century 21 At Tahoe Paradise, by email.
She says most of the buyers are purchasing second homes.
Average home prices in South Lake Tahoe are up 4% since this time last year.
In the Northeast, Steve Clay, a real estate broker and team leader at Keller Williams Realty covering Upper Cape Cod, is also upbeat about the climate for vacation home buying.
After an "awful winter" with record snow fall, business really picked up in mid-to-late March, says Clay.
"And it hasn't let up since," he adds. "I think we're experiencing a general market improvement and also some pent-up demand created by an unusually harsh winter."
He anticipates a "good season" for vacation home sales.
"A lot of it is due to an improved economy and improving job market," he adds.
At the end of the first quarter, his team had 24 properties under contract vs. 18 last year.
He says most agents at his firm say second homes are the biggest part of their business.
Allan Dechert, co-owner of Ferguson Dechert Real Estate in Avalon, N.J., is also upbeat about the vacation-home market in the Stone Harbor and Avalon beach areas.
"I'm optimistic this year will be a great year," he told IBD.
Second-home sales activity was "pretty steady" in 2014 and into the year's fourth quarter, he says.

So far this year — despite the harsh winter weather — the activity through the first quarter was "really good," Dechert said. This year's first quarter was "significantly above" last year's for his team in dollars and in units.
He says purchases have been priced across the board. In March, for example, sale prices ranged from $460,000 to $2.5 million.

Overall, the total sales inventory on Stone Harbor and Avalon, is down 20% from a year ago, Dechert says, adding that things are "tightening up" with fewer properties on the market, which means pricing will go up.
Arizona's Experience
Kris Anderson, team leader for Your Premier Team at Re/Max Excalibur in Scottsdale, Ariz., is also seeing some pickup in vacation home buying activity.
In the first quarter, 15.2% of all sales in Arizona's Maricopa County — which includes Phoenix — were for vacation homes, up from 9% in the 2014 fourth quarter, she told IBD.
In the first quarter of 2015, vacation home sales for the county were up 1% from a year earlier.
Another indication that activity is up in the county: Pending home sales under contract were up 7% from a year earlier in the first quarter and the median sales price increased by 5.5%.

Vacation homes made up 15% of total pending sales, the same percentage as last year, Anderson said, adding, "that's not a great percentage, but we're happy with 15%."Vacation-home demand has been on a steady climb as a strong stock market, low interest rates and tempting deals have prompted high-end households to spend more freely on second residences and summer getaways.The push comes as more high-net-worth buyers have opted to put some of the earnings they've gained from a rising stock market into second homes in spots that support a more leisure lifestyle.Contributing to the increased demand are baby boomers home shopping for a place to vacation now, and retire to later.Real estate brokers in resort locales from Massachusetts' Cape Cod to Nevada's Lake Tahoe report brisk second-home buying activity during the year's first quarter.And real estate experts say the vacation home market is heating up."It's a very good time for vacation homes," Daren Blomquist, vice president at RealtyTrac told IBD. GDP growth tumbles GDP grew at an annual rate of 0.2% in the government's Q1 initial read. That was below even the sharply reduced consensus forecast of 1%. Exports slumped 7.2% in Q1, likely thanks to a stronger dollar. Consumer spending rose 1.9%, less than half the 4.4% gain in Q4. Government spending — federal, state and local — declined…

Sales of new homes came in at an annual pace of 481,000 units in March — hardly the 518,000 that economists had been expecting. That represented an 11.4% drop from February. But there were some important caveats. February's read of 543,000 newly constructed homes sold was a seven-year high, and March levels were up 19.4% for the year. There was…

Shares of homebuilder PulteGroup (PHM) on Thursday sank to their lowest level since November after the company reported first-quarter results that missed views due to fewer closings in what its CEO called "a sustained but slow recovery" in the housing market. Shares caved 7.7% to 20.03 in the stock market today, a fall likely compounded by the 11.4 % drop…

Home prices surged in February, according to the S&P/Case-Shiller index. The 20-City index rose 5.0% for the year, the fourth straight month to see an acceleration. Yearly price gains fell by more than half during 2014, a step that was supposed to restore some normalcy to the market and entice more buyers. But as inventory remains tight, prices have started…

Horton (DHI), the nation's largest homebuilder, said Wednesday that home sales in its second quarter, ended in March, grew 38% to $2.3 billion on 8,243 homes closed, up…

U.S. stocks showed hesitation Wednesday after the previous session's strong price gains. The Nasdaq slipped 0.4%, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.3% and 0.2%, respectively. Volume in the stock market today dropped vs. Tuesday's already below-average pace.

Blue chips were mostly down. Only a handful of stocks in the Dow rose and those in tiny steps. On the downside, Chevron (CVX) carved off 1% in slow turnover as West Texas intermediate crude oil fell 3.5%. Chevron, an integrated oil company, has rebounded about 30% off its late August low but remains about 33% off its July 2014 high.

An integrated oil company is involved in many facets of the business: exploration, production, refining and distribution. From late June 2014, when crude oil began its fast price slide, the price of oil is now down 64%; U.S. explorers, down 63%; integrated, down 41%; and refiners, down 21%.

In the IBD 50 — a list of the best stocks in fundamentals and technicals — mortgage software provider Ellie Mae (ELLI) took the hardest hit, dropping more than 2%. But volume was about 20% below average.
Housing-related stocks got some bad news as November pending home sales dropped unexpectedly.

However, homebuilder D.R. Horton (DHI), a Leaderboard stock, shrugged the news off. Call it a spring comeback for housing? Existing-home sales leapt to the fastest rate in 18 months in March. The annual rate of 5.19 million beat expectations and marked the sixth-straight month of annual increases. In March, that was a 10.4% gain vs. 2014, the highest annual jump since August 2013.
